B000957O82|4.0|Will Smith stars in this movie as Alex Hitchens, a suave, smooth- talking fellow who knows his business and performs it well. The thing that makes the situation a little different is that Alex isn't in a traditional business. No, \\"Hitch\\" (as people call him) is in the business of love. He helps shy, awkward men find dates by coaching them on the right things to say and the right gestures to make. He is convinced that a man can get any woman if he follows the rules.<br /><br />Smith is the star of this movie, and he fits the part very well. It doesn't hurt that he has a fine supporting cast to back him up, including the likes of Kevin James, Eva Mendes, and Amber Valletta. I felt they all played their respective roles quite nicely, although I did find Eva Mendes character a little annoying after a while. On the other hand, Mendes is the one person who provides some suspense. She is a gossip columnist and the love interest of Will Smith. She isn't completely stable and she has erected an emotional fence when it comes to men. You don't really know what she is going to do from one scene to the next, and this makes her character a little more entertaining.<br /><br />What I like best about Hitch is that it gets you thinking about certain issues about dating, attraction, and ethics. Smith's character is convinced that a man can get the woman of his dreams, even if he isn't very good looking in comparison. There is some truth to this. I don't think any man can get any woman, but it is generally easier for a man with average or below average looks to get a girl who looks better than the other way around. Also, as Smith's character points out near the end, he only provides a catalyst for his clients to get the woman they want. What he is doing is ethical because it is the client himself that is really doing the work. If a relationship isn't meant to be, then no amount of coaching will help.<br /><br />One thing that I didn't like about this movie occurred near the beginning when Smith talked directly to the camera. Unless a film is a documentary, I don't think it's a good idea to have the actors and actresses talk to the camera, like they know a film is being made. Besides that, I think the pacing could have been picked up a little bit in places, too. But overall, \\"Hitch\\" still ranks as a good, entertaining motion picture. The performances and the messages it sends about dating make it worth a look.when Smith talked directly to the camera. Unless a film is a documentary, I don't think it's a good idea to have the actors and actresses talk to the camera, like they know a film is being made. Besides that, I think the pacing could have been picked up a little bit in places, too. But overall, \\"Hitch\\" still ranks as a good, entertaining motion picture. The performances and the messages it sends about dating make it worth a look.

1565847032|5.0|When I brought this book I assumed that the term 'indespensable' would mean that it would be a collection of excerpts of his writing - rather it is a collection of transcripts of public forum discussion. The results were unputdownable for me as they have the air of having Noam Chomsky over for a chat over the dinner table and serve as an immensely accessible and unpretentious introduction to his thinking - by that virtue alone this definitely deserves to be called truly indespensible.  <br /> <br />The chosen transcripts are all so carefully chosen and thoughtfully editorialised as to represent his views on the widest possible range of issues. There will be something in this for everyone as a consequence, with everything here having as much or even more immediate relevancy to our post-9/11 times as it did when first published. The rise and fall of the Soviet Union, the Korean war, the Vietnam war, the real meaning of the Watergate incident, the Middle East conflict, the need for enviromental reform - these and so many things are covered in a dazzling tour de force of thought. Chomsky bravely says things with aplomb that nobody else would dare to say - in case you too ended up knowing too much.  <br /> <br />This is a book that makes so much in our age seem so much more transparent, when the media has become a tool of the political propaganda machinery linked as it is to the moguls of their industry. It is scarcely possible to see any event in the last 80+ years of world history in the same light, such is the revelatory nature of the thought presented here that literally makes the scales fall from your eyes. <br /> <br />Subsequently this book has encouraged me to read other of his writings but I am immensely pleased that I started here. I have also lent this book to others - and judging by the postive responses I have had I doubt I am going to see it back for a very long time. I unconditionally recommend this book with whole-hearted enthusiasm and think anyone wouldfind something personally affecting here. This is a book that truly everyone should read just to empower themselves with the ability to see through so much politically driven mass media distortion (my euphemism for propaganda) that we are all so thoroughly saturated in.

B0009353IW|5.0|Now this is more like it... Several of the tunes are very different from Cooder's non-soundtrack music and we get a chance to hear his producer/arranger's mind in a new context. I especially liked the structure and harmonies of the first tune. The chords in the final section are reminiscent of the very sweet and funky East LA music from the late 60's and early 70's that I remember hearing on the radio as a kid.  Some of the voicings are identical to some of Bill Evans' harmonies too, believe or not. The reference to the common refrain in Cuban music, \\"vamos pa'l monte\\" is kinda cool, too. <br /> <br />The tunes in Spanish shouldn't present any problem for any gringos who can read the English translations. As a 3rd generation native southern Californian I can easily identify with the import of this song and I support the remarks of the other reviewers who share my background. Maybe a person must experience the type of \\"development\\" that completely destroys a way of life to understand this song properly. <br /> <br />Lalo Guerrero was wonderful on this disc. I can't get enough of 'em. The vocals on \\"El UFO Cayo\\" are gorgeous; beautiful technique and expression, and the lyrics, again, are sad, dry, resigned and very hip. If people don't get it, I feel sorry for them. <br /> <br />The arrangement on \\"3 Cool Cats\\" is funky and airtight. These are some really good performances by these musicians. Willie G does his thing to perfection here. The lovely melody on \\"In my room\\" and Cooder's cranky singing work really well with the restrained guitar and the lyrical and atmospheric piano. It is an effective shift in the programming, too.  <br /> <br />It is very good to hear Ry and Flaco Jimenez playing conjunto again. What rich and beautiful accordian playing. In fact, all the Chicano music is excellent, unsurprising since this disc features such important and historic musicians. <br />  <br />There are many other high points in this disc. I think many people react to music that is slightly unfamiliar or new by immediately rejecting it. This is kinda dumb. If you take the time to actually listen to what the record tries to achieve (rather than just immediately react) maybe you'll find something good in it. In any case, this is an excellent effort, with very imaginative and effective lyrics, interesting and superb music and great performances.

0553212540|5.0|In books, magazines, television, etc. in the English-speaking world, we often come across references made to Oscar Wilde, as many people quote his witty sayings and lines.  Having come across so many of these references and quotations myself, I was hesitant to pick up any of his works, assuming that to understand and appreciate Wilde I would have to be some kind of a literary scholar. Let me set the record straight: this is definitely not the case at all, as Oscar Wilde is very down to earth and easy to understand.<br /><br />He is a gifted writer and I understand now why people quote him so much. He's a master at putting thoughts to pen and paper so ingeniously. After I found out for myself what he was all about, I regret that I never read his books earlier. I picked up this book that included various works and I was truly amazed at his genius. He interlaces humor with the heavy so cleverly.<br /><br />In all of his works you can easily identify a so-called \\"dandy\\", a male character whose one role is to make flippant but ironically true remarks to the dismay of stuffy characters. The quotes we so often see or hear are usually remarks uttered by one of Wilde's dandies. Offering tongue-in-cheek humor with wholehearted honesty, Wilde called a spade, a spade but could so with such brilliant wit. Oh if only I could be even half as gifted with the pen!<br /><br />I am not going to write about any plots of the stories and plays, as other readers have done that already. I simply wanted to say that if you have never read anything by Wilde, I highly recommend you do. I am confidant you will enjoy.  You could end up like me, frantically longing to get your hands on as much of his writing as you can.

B00000DQSS|5.0|Released in September of 1980, Kate Bush's 3rd album \\"Never for Ever\\" is, as the saying goes, \\"through the roof\\"--this is a phenomenal piece of work.  It's very all over the map, yet it flows stunningly well as an album--in other words, \\"Never for Ever\\" takes you on an exhilirating journey.  Kate is absolutely one of the most amazing vocalists ever--incredibly expressive, versatile, making great use of her extraordinary range, and a master of nuance.  And of course, there's also Kate's astonishing songwriting abilities and her magical piano playing.  The creepy album-opener \\"Babooshka\\" is, for lack of better term, a twisted pop-rocker, and it's incredibly tuneful with great tension and an explosive chorus; its tells a tale of a woman secretly playing tricks on her husband, making it rather reminiscent of \\"The Pina Colada Song\\" by Rupert Holmes in a lyrical sense, though it's a totally different ball of wax from a musical perspective.  The drum machine-based \\"Delius (Song of Summer)\\" is gorgeous with its melodically rich piano and masterfully textured sound--with the music and Kate's soaring vocals, it evokes the feeling of a wonderful starry night.  \\"Blow Away (For Bill)\\" is a remarkably intriguing tribute to pop/ rock stars who died young--the chorus features bizarre pronunciation (done this way intentionally, no doubt) and makes reference to Minnie Riperton, Keith Moon, Sid Vicious, Buddy Holly, and Sandy Denny, with Marc Bolan also referenced in the last verse; the song achieves an incredibly bittersweet quality, thanks to the wonderful sighing chord changes, soaring melodicism, and the heart-tuggingly emotional lyrics.  She moves into Celtic-flavored territory on the enchanting \\"All We Ever Look For\\"--it's about relationships between children and their parents, and the lyrics ring very true indeed.  \\"The Wedding List\\" features incredibly twisted lyrics sung from the point of view of a possessed, jealous woman--quite disturbing subject matter, but the drama and Kate's devilish vocals are captivating.  Kate serves up a really fun rocker with the cartoonishly erotic \\"Violin\\" which fittingly features quasi-atonal violin work--she gets a little carried away with her orgasmic yelps, but the hilariously obsessive, manic chorus is a blast.  The musically gentle, mandolin-laden \\"Army Dreamers\\" is another sumptuously melodic song and has extremely poignant lyrics.  She ends the album with the chilling \\"Breathing\\"--sung from the point of view of an unborn child, it takes a brilliant look at problems of nuclear power which had become of great concern in the late '70s, and it also makes reference to mothers who smoke during pregnancy (one of the saddest things a woman can do); the song does suffer a bit from the melodramatic chant at the end, but it's a pretty minor complaint on an album that really blows you away.  I really want to point out that the production values on this album are really amazing--pristinely recorded, sublime sound quality, cool use of sound effects, truly a timeless piece of work; ironically, no producer's credit is listed, though it's an easy guess that Kate was definitely calling the shots.  You definitely have to give credit though to the numerous ace musicians she has on here helping her out.  The fact that this album still sounds like such a startlingly original breakthrough after nearly 25 years after its original release is a testament to Kate's one-of-a-kind nature.  \\"Never for Ever\\" is a definite must-have recording.

1565847032|3.0|Before reading Understanding Power, I knew of Noam Chomsky only by his (formidable) reputation as a linguist and author of Manufacturing Consent, which I had not, at the time, read. In truth, I was prompted to buy Understanding Power - said to be a good collection of his works, having read, and been perplexed by, Chomsky's effusive praise of a less-than-convincing book about the nastiness of corporations (\\"The Corporation\\", by Joel Bakan.) I was curious as to how such a respected, academic, intelligent commentator could come to be praising such a bone-headed book.<br /><br />Well, I am curious no more.<br /><br />This is a nicely edited, packaged edition, which benefits from the fact that it seems to contain mostly transcripts of Socratic-style \\"teach-ins\\" (love-ins, more like) that Chomsky has conducted over the last few years. It's conversational and very easy to read: far from being weighed down by the carefully premeditated prose of a stuffy academic, Understanding Power positively zings with invective, humour, and oratory. Parts of it are funny (not always intentionally so), parts fascinating, Chomsky's command of the \\"received\\" facts of recent political history (and his self-declared \\"true\\" ones) is consistently impressive.<br /><br />Not only does this book give you a very clear exposition of Chomsky's perspective, it is very entertaining as it does it. Credit, therefore, to the editors who have presumably sifted through weeks of audio tape, and have cleaned up and contextualised to add to the reading pleasure. They've also compiled footnotes of greater length than the text, which are available for spods online.<br /><br />While his facts maybe impeccably marshalled, many of the conclusions at which Chomsky arrives - particular in the field of economics - are obviously baloney (it is basically conspiracy and paranoia writ on a scale even James Ellroy would baulk at) but it's maddeningly difficult to nail down exactly why. But this evening, in a taxi on the way home from my wage-slavery (ahem), on page 216, I nailed it: Chomsky's richest polemic is almost all unfalsifiable. There are no conceivable facts you could present to Chomsky that would lead him to say, \\"You know what? You're right! I've got this all completely wrong!\\" Arguing against Noam Chomsky would be like arguing against a born-again Christian. Facts are construed to fit the theory, and not the other way around.<br /><br />That quality - falsifiability - is what distinguishes valid argument from dogma. The fact that something is capable of being proven false is what gives it explanatory traction in the world. If a statement is true for all possible circumstances, it's either circular, tautological or it bears no relation to the world we live in.<br /><br />So when the stooges in his audience meekly suggest that his proposal for how to really manage an economy (namely: everyone pulls together and works towards the common good, no-one fights, no-one wants more than their fair share, everyone co-operates - utterly brilliant, isn't it?) has been tried in a few places, and it fell apart pretty quickly, Chomsky's retort is 'but that wasn't REALLY socialism! That was actually disguised CAPITALISM!' hence - objection is defined away, as opposed to being defended.<br /><br />Nonetheless, there are still some glaring facts which Chomsky can't explain away: The most obvious is that if the media and corporate elites are so indoctrinated, so suppressive of \\"dissident\\" views like Chomsky's, then how can Chomsky himself have been such a roaring success? A search within Amazon on \\"Noam Chomsky\\" lists 536 books (ten times as many as for \\"Rush Limbaugh\\", five times as many as for \\"P J O'Rourke\\", and only 8 fewer than for \\"George Bush\\"!). Chomsky is a global superstar, an arch propagandist, a fantastic brand, and though he commends his disciples not to take his word for it, legions of them (most notably the slurpers who sit cross-legged at his feet in the pages of this book) simply do. No-one subjects his patter to sustained criticism - possibly because it is no more fun than arguing with a born-again Christian. I suspect what sticks in Chomsky's craw more than anything else isn't that he's suppressed by his political opponents - he simply isn't - it's that he's happily tolerated and, for the most part, ignored.<br /><br />And it's not really hard to see why. On one hand, Chomsky has little enough faith in the intellectual integrity of his common man to blame the prevalence of consumerism and capitalism on his brainwashing by the media and the corporate elite, but enough faith in it to suppose that some sort of anarcho-syndicalist communal form of existence for humankind is even remotely viable. He may well be right in his first assessment (but if they're happy, so what, actually?); the second is ludicrous. But it's the only solution he can come up with - such is the poverty of his constructive analysis. It is one thing to criticise, quite another to propose a constructive alternative - and I'm afraid consensual, non coercive, state-free social planning (if by that you don't mean naked capitalism, and trust me, Chomsky doesn't) just ain't it.<br /><br />Lest you think I'm exaggerating about Chomsky's skills as a propagandist, check out this little piece of disinformation: The dust jacket of Understanding Power quotes the New York Times as describing Chomsky as \\"arguably the most important intellectual alive\\". Well, if you read the book, you'll know that Chomsky is no fan of the New York Times, so I was surprised by this quote - surprised enough to Google on it to see if I could find the original. And I did: properly contextualised, it reads \\"...Noam Chomsky is arguably the most important intellectual alive today. He is also a disturbingly divided intellectual. On the one hand there is a large body of revolutionary and highly technical linguistic scholarship, much of it too difficult for anyone but the professional linguist or philosopher; on the other, an equally substantial body of political writings, accessible to any literate person but often maddeningly simple-minded\\".<br /><br />Haha, Professor Chomsky: Caught red-handed! *Now* who is \\"manufacturing consent\\"?<br /><br />At the end of the day, the most withering criticism of Noam Chomsky's political outlook comes not from the New York Times, but from the much-beloved satire on the anarcho-syndicalist peasant in Monty Python and the Holy Grail quoted in the title of this review.<br /><br />I must say, I tend to side with King Arthur's ultimate view, as he trudges away, bored and frustrated with totally pointless conversation.<br /><br />Python Afficionados will know what I mean.<br /><br />Olly Buxton<br /><br />*******<br />Clarification: When reading the book I had assumed that Chomsky was some sort of cognitive relativist. I've since spent quite a lot of time reading around Chomsky, and it turns out that he's anything but: The linguistic \\"nativism\\" championed by Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker is perhaps the last bastion of intellectual support for moral and cognitive objectivism, and this world view is apparent (ironically) in Chomsky's political writing. My fault: I guess I just couldn't credit that anyone still seriously advanced this perspective, especially from the Left.<br /><br />For when Chomsky says \\"seemingly unobjectionable state of affairs X is actually a malicious conspiracy Y\\", his criticism relies on the *falsehood* of explanation X and the *truth* of explanation Y. Cognitive relativism is no friend of Chomsky's at all: On the contrary, it undermines his position by saying that explanations X and Y are alternative descriptions of the same state of affairs, and *in the absence of data which are inconsistent with one or other explanation* ones subscription to one or the other is almost certainly a matter of historical contingency, and (*in the absence of contrary data*) there is no means of adjudicating between those explanations.<br /><br />Chomsky's explanations tend to rely on \\"hidden hands\\" (conspiracies between capitalists, government agencies and so forth) which are characterised by nothing so much as their lack of evidence - indeed, this very lack of evidence of conspiracy is often the \\"clincher\\" by which Chomsky claims the conspiracy must exist.<br /><br />Olly Buxtoncessible to any literate person but often maddeningly simple-minded\\".    Haha, Professor Chomsky: Caught red-handed! *Now* who is \\"manufacturing consent\\"?    At the end of the day, the most withering criticism of Noam Chomsky's political outlook comes not from the New York Times, but from the much-beloved satire on the anarcho-syndicalist peasant in Monty Python and the Holy Grail quoted in the title of this review.    I must say, I tend to side with King Arthur's ultimate view, as he trudges away, bored and frustrated with totally pointless conversation.     Python Afficionados will know what I mean.    Olly Buxton    *******  Clarification: When reading the book I had assumed that Chomsky was some sort of cognitive relativist. I've since spent quite a lot of time reading around Chomsky, and it turns out that he's anything but: The linguistic \\"nativism\\" championed by Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker is perhaps the last bastion of intellectual support for moral and cognitive objectivism, and this world view is apparent (ironically) in Chomsky's political writing. My fault: I guess I just couldn't credit that anyone still seriously advanced this perspective, especially from the Left.     For when Chomsky says \\"seemingly unobjectionable state of affairs X is actually a malicious conspiracy Y\\", his criticism relies on the *falsehood* of explanation X and the *truth* of explanation Y. Cognitive relativism is no friend of Chomsky's at all: On the contrary, it undermines his position by saying that explanations X and Y are alternative descriptions of the same state of affairs, and *in the absence of data which are inconsistent with one or other explanation* ones subscription to one or the other is almost certainly a matter of historical contingency, and (*in the absence of contrary data*) there is no means of adjudicating between those explanations.    Chomsky's explanations tend to rely on \\"hidden hands\\" (conspiracies between capitalists, government agencies and so forth)which are characterised by nothing so much as their lack of evidence - indeed, this very lack of evidence of conspiracy is often the \\"clincher\\" by which Chomsky claims the conspiracy must exist.    Olly Buxton

B00009MGGI|5.0|This is without a doubt, one of the very best dramatic series I have ever seen.  Why on earth hasn't Masterpeice Theater replayed it?  Given what PBS has recently gone through with its governing board and accusations of \\"liberal bias\\", perhaps it's understandable that they don't want to be seen to be criticizing our political masters, but the point has already been made.  Why leave it up to mealy-mouthed special-effects fests like \\"Retread of the Sith\\", when works like this do so with so much more poise and precision?<br /><br />The House of Cards series combines superlative acting skills with pointed commentary on power, ambition and politics.  Three great scripts (I disagree with those who say Part 3 was weaker than the others, but more on this below), and superb directing and acting make this the highlight of my summer viewing for sure.  For US viewers, this series is as excellent as the Sopranos, and Homicide and for similar reasons (interesting characters, wonderful actors and compelling plot lines).<br /><br />*General spoiler alert*<br /><br />This series is many things to many people, but it is to my mind, first and foremost a Shakespearean drama.  Screenwriter Andrew Davies makes this quite clear in his discussions of the series.  To that end, the most important thing in the series is our villain and his arc from charming, ruthless monster to cornered animal.<br /><br />How sad that Ian Richardson hasn't been given the chance to display his incredible acting talents to a wider audience.  His portrayl of the caiman-like Conservative politician Francis Urquhart  captured the simultaneously mesmerizing and sheer evil quality of Urquhart beautifully (Richardson won a BAFTA in 1991 for House of Cards and was nominated again in 1993 for To Play the King, and again in 1996 for The Final Cut). Richardson's training in theater (he was with the Royal Shakespeare Company for 15 years) stand him in excellent stead here, but the most compelling pieces of acting he does are often expressed with no more than a glance at the camera, or a lifted eyebrow or corner of the mouth.  The man's a genius in my humble opinion.<br /><br />House of Cards has had an interesting effect on political behavior in the UK in particular. The non-denial denial \\"You might say that... I couldn't possibly comment\\" that was one of Urquhart's favorite catchphrases has become established usage among British public figures, including then-Prime Minister John Major.  It's also been acronymized for use in cyberspace as YMSTICPC.<br /><br />As a number of other people have pointed out, this series strongly evokes specific Shakespearean works, notably MacBeth, and Richard III.  There are however, echoes of other tragedies as well, particularly King Lear (Urquhart's soliloquy on being \\"a father of daughters\\" for one, and the use of the \\"sharper than a serpent's tooth\\" quotation) and Titus Andronicus (F.U.'s ease with violence, and the black humor throughout the series) particularly in Part 3 (The Final Cut).  I suppose if one wanted to play the \\"match the series with the play\\" game, Part 1 would be analogous to the first half of MacBeth, Part 2 to Richard  (up to the Battle of Bosworth), and Part 3 would be Lear with Act V of Richard thrown in for good measure.<br /><br />Thus the supposed \\"weaknesses\\" in F.U.'s behavior in Part 3: his tendency to surround himself with weaklings, his descent into open violence, and his inability to \\"smell the mood\\" of his colleagues can in fact be better understood as classic Shakespearean indicators of the ruler who has finally lost his edge through age, hubris or paranoia (or some combination of all 3).<br /><br />Much has been made of Mrs. Urquhart's similarity to Lady MacBeth, but she's really more like the homicidal Goneril in \\"Lear\\": None of Lady M's weak-kneed descent into madness for her.  In fact, the Tragedy of Francis Urquhart (apart from the mayhem he inflicts -indirectly depicted by the director for the most part, on the well-being of ordinary British people) might well be most clearly expressed in the treacherousness or self-servingness of those who surround him at the end.<br /><br />Some people believe that this series does not translate well for American audiences, my sense is that this is far from the case. Certainly some of the more subtle satire and the British cultural references might be lost, (such as the reference to the children's hand-puppet character Sooty - think Lamb Chop or Elmo as a stuffed bear) and it certainly helps to have a passing familiarity with British Parliamentary procedure (in particular the wonderful institution of \\"Prime Minister's Question Time\\").<br /><br />Nevertheless these are minor details in the overall scheme of things.  British politics has no monopoly on stupidity, manipulation or naked ambition.  Viewers in other countries will have no trouble recognizing their own domestic versions of F.U.,  some perhaps in their own workplaces.  Can we recognize this same behavior (admittedly with much less wit and sophistication) in some people in the current US administration? You might think that, you might very well think that, ... I couldn't possibly comment.the most part, on the well-being of ordinary British people) might well be most clearly expressed in the treacherousness or self-servingness of those who surround him at the end. <br /> <br />Some people believe that this series does not translate well for American audiences, my sense is that this is far from the case. Can we recognize this same behavior (admittedly with much less wit and sophistication) in some people in the current US administration? You might think that, you might very well think that, ... I couldn't possibly comment.
0451163516|4.0|The best part about this book is that halfway through the story, I couldn't figure out what ending to hope for.  Follett does an excellent job of creating sympathy for each character, even the evil ones, a characteristic found in some of his other novels as well.  All of them are in very precarious situations and each possible outcome spells disaster for some other character in the book.  On the one hand, I wanted the assassin to carry out the murder for his own sake and for the prevention of WWI(even though it did happen), but I also wanted the Russian prince to survive because he is a good character and it would be disastrous for the entire Walden family.  Rarely does an author present such a conflict, most resort to the hope of a happy ending which the reader knows is inevitable but this one is definitely unique.  There is no true happy ending.  <br /> <br />This is an all-around solid book.  You really do feel for the characters and their dilemmas.  The story never drags, each chapter has some kind of contribution to the overall quality and the high stakes involved ensure the reader's attention for the duration of the book.  Worth the $8.

The Porsche 962 they were driving (the first one to race in the US derived from the European rules 956) had just retired due to a blown turbo and the engineer showed me the engine and what broke and the Andrettis gave me their impressions of a car that went on to dominate sports car racing for a decade.

0805211063|5.0|This unfinished chef-d'oeuvre begins with the hero (a man named \\"K.\\") entering an unknown village where a castle looms overhead from a far off hilltop.  Later the reader is told that K. was summoned by The Castle to be employed as a land-surveyor, though there is always the nagging suspicion that this is not true, as he is never admitted entrance to The Castle.  From this point on, the book concerns itself with K.'s obsession with reaching The Castle.  Why, and for what benefit, the reader does not know.  Still, whether or not we feel sympathy for the hero or interest for his goal, is of little importance compared to the interest we take in the events that seem to just lurk around the corner at any moment.  The reader constantly has the impression that everything is just about to explode.  `The Caste' is one of the few books I have read more than once, which I have enjoyed every time.  Having just finished the book for the third time, I felt as though it were the first, and it was sad to come to the end (though remember, there is no real end as the work was never finished).  Kafka's genius lies in setting a mood to a place and creating a timeless and eerie setting.  Like the strange version of Paris in the great masterpiece by Roman Payne, 'Crepuscule'; or the fortress in Nabokov's brilliant book, 'Invitation to a Beheading', the unknown village in 'The Castle' is a bizarre world that seems to live independently of the rest of the world and independently of all time.  Even Kafka's mention of telephones and other modern objects seems not to detract from the timeless world he has invented.  For writers and those who study literature, `The Caste' is an illuminating guide to great literary style.  For readers and lovers of literature, `The Caste' is the perfect book to get lost in.

0393324818|5.0|I have read all the current business books, but Moneyball was definitely among the best.      For one thing, I thought that the book was going to be about baseball.  It is more like an MBA project study ... \\" Your assignment is to build a major league baseball team with a payroll of $40M that will compete with, and defeat, the New York Yankees with a payroll more than three times higher.\\"      Only, it is a real case.    And the results are in the paper every morning.    For another, I thought that it was a book about Billy Beane. Frankly, it is more of a book about the repudiation of all the past, present and future Billy Beanes - the talented \\"5 tool\\" teenagers, most failures - as they become a lesser part of the overall strategy to building a successful, and sustainable, business model.    And finally, Moneyball is a book from which you can learn - and use in your daily business, even if it is not baseball.    For those of us who must put together strategies, this book is a must-read primer.  Beane relies on different sets of data to make decisions,  identifies new metrics on which to evaluate talent, eliminates \\"old school\\" thinking from cigar chomping talent scouts who previously had made the recommendations that resulted in more misses than hits over the years, and develops a methodology for determining the relative value of players before cashing them in for developmental (e.g., lower cost) opportunities.    Not only does his strategy work (as evidenced by copy cat GMs in recent years), his Oakland team makes money - and lots of it.  And, he did it by allowing two MVPs and other \\"name\\" players to move to other teams because their cost-to-value no longer fit within the Oakland value proposition.    What this book has given me is the curiosity to seek different data to investigate and evaluate facts in order to find new answers to old questions.  Actually, when it is read with Freakonomics as part of a day-night double-header, Moneyball will get your brain working with every turn of the page.

Someone's got to help the  middle class and poor see what our parents were not able to teach us. America is still a young country, and many of us come from immigrants and slaves, so the mentality that is passed on from generation to generation may be primarily what we're taught in public school: get good grades, get a good job and work hard. We all know that one does not get rich doing the \\"right thing\\". The extra stuff that we don't learn in school, or the courses most of us avoid taking since we want to pass our classes and get out of school, is about numbers, fractions, percentages, compounded interest and so on. These concepts are foreign to us and frankly, the average person is socialized to avoid the unknown. B0002OERI0|5.0|This is the best album ever created by mankind. They've truley outdone themselves here, proven that they're more than 3 immature punk kids singing about masturbation, sex, and drugs.  American Idiot is a punk opera, an entire story about a guy named Jesus who meets people like St. Jimmy and Whatsername along the way, people who change his life in very significant ways.  American Idiot is more than just a cd, if you listen to it you're listening to a story.  And if you listen closely, you will find many different political, societal, and psychological themes.  In that way it's just like reading a book or watching a movie, but it's music, which makes it one of the most original cd's ever created.  In an age of very crappy pop singers who don't even sing, it's great to see a band who sings, writes, plays, and even produces their own stuff.  The drumming and the guitars are too great to put into words, and the the singing is also phenomenal.  Every single aspect has been perfected; Green Day has covered every single detail.  They truley deserve to be paid millions of dollars, because American Idiot has changed not only my life, but so many other people's.  There'es so much variety on this cd.  You hear pure punk songs like American Idiot, St. Jimmy, and Holiday with very catchy melodies.  You hear very personal, slower paced songs like When September Ends where Billie describes the death of his father.  You hear 5 part, 9-minute songs like Jesus of Suburbia and Homecoming where every one of those 5 parts os distincely different form each other.  In Extraordinary Girl you hear Indian flutes and drumming, and in other songs u hear styles that are reminiscent of classic rock.  Despite such differences in the songs, they're all magnificently bonded together with wonderful transitions.  Each song is its own chapter in this novel, but all of them blend together very nicely.    Anybody who says that this cd is anything short of amazing is just too stupid, too ignorant, or too lazy to actually listen closely to the music and interpret the underlying meanings of every single line.  If you carefully go through the entire cd, you will be dumbfounded.  If you think this cd is just a bunch of catchy radio tunes, or that it's just a bunch of stuff bashing Bush, well you're SEVERELY WRONG.  If you actually listen to it you will see the very many different aspects of it all.  Green Day has proven themselves musical geniuses for putting out this album.  The only way you cannot like this cd is if you either haven't listened to it, or if you misunderstood it due to your own ignorance to interpret it. (...) American Idiot is by far the biggest and best accomplishment of any rockers out there, so thank you Green Day for your hard work and dedication that created this masterpiece!
0060934719|5.0|I need to just take for granted that almost everything Neil Gaiman writes I will love.  I have stayed away from two of his books, Coraline and Stardust, for awhile because they have been often described as a young adult or children stories.  Having read both Neverwhere and American Gods and loving them, it took me awhile to finally swallow \\"my pride\\" and read books I thought were meant for little children not for everyone.  A silly and arrogant move, I know now.<br /><br />I read Stardust in one sitting.  It almost reads itself.  The pages fly by so quickly and easily that before you know it you're half way through the novel and that doesn't stop you from reading the other half.  It is a fairytale in one aspect, but something else entirely also.  It begins in the town of Wall where a wall has been placed keeping people of the UK from the otherside.  One day every nine years, the guards leave their posts and the people can mingle with those from the otherside, the Faerie side.  That's all I will really say about the plot.  Like every other Gaiman novel I have read, the story is best when you know little or nothing about it.<br /><br />Like most faerie tales, the story begins with love.  But, unlike stories like the Little Mermaid or Cinderella or countless other Grim stories, it goes a little further.  What begins as a \\"simple\\" quest to win someone's affection grows into a coming of age story where the protagonist learns more about himself and about life.  It's a grand story filled with vivid images and great characters.  Every character, from those who are given a paragraph to those who are the main protagonists or antagonists are filled with character.  Much like every other Gaiman novel, it's easy to fall in love with the characters as real breathing things.<br /><br />I'm not sure what else to say.  I wanted to write this review mainly to persuade those on the fence to read it and give it a chance.  It's filled with dark images, images of love both true and fake, and a great story.  If you enjoy Gaiman's other works, don't pass this one over.  Leave your preconceived notions at the door and I think you'll find it's a terrific read just as engaging as Neverwhere or American Gods..  If you enjoy Gaiman's other works, don't pass this one over.  Leave your preconceived notions at the door and I think you'll find it's a terrific read just as engaging as Neverwhere or American Gods.
B00005221M|5.0|Set in 1757 during the French and Indian War, \\"The Last of the Mohicans\\" is based (but does not strictly adhere to) the novel by James Fenimore Cooper. It is a lavish, exquisite production, with Daniel Day-Lewis fantastic as Hawkeye, showing a screen magnetism that is more intense than in any other part he has played. His chemistry with beautiful Cora, wonderfully portrayed by Madeleine Stowe is palpable, and they manage to have one of the most erotic love scenes ever filmed, without shedding a single garment. The film has many battles scenes, and could be categorized as \\"action/adventure,\\" but I always think of it as being primarily a romance, and it is also an excellent depiction of the early days of the settlers, and their many struggles.<br /><br />The setting is western New York, with much of the action taking place at Fort William Henry, but it was actually filmed in the lush and scenic wilderness of North Carolina, with superb cinematography by Dante Spinotti, and a lovely score by Trevor Jones and Randy Edelman. Michael Mann's direction keeps a terrific pace, and the cast is wonderful, and includes Russell Means, marvelous in his film debut as Chingachgook, Eric Schweig as Uncas, Wes Studi as the revengeful Magua, Johdi May as Cora's sister Alice, and Steven Waddington impressive as Major Duncan Heyward.<br /><br />VHS vs. DVD: The Director's Expanded Edition, though still a brilliant film, is a disappointment, and I will be keeping my old letterbox VHS, which though worn, actually has a brighter picture than the DVD. The \\"expanded\\" portions add little to the enjoyment of the film, and the deletions hurt it. The incomplete conversation between Hawkeye and Cora in the burial ground is left hanging in the air, and the absence of Clannad's song, \\"I Will Find You\\", takes much of the magic from the scene where Hawkeye follows the captured Cora.<br />Total running time for the VHS, 114 minutes, DVD 117 minutes.
0380789035|4.0|This was the second Neil Gaiman novel I read.  Coming off of the high that was the magnificient Neverwhere, I hungrily started reading American Gods.<br /><br />The concept is definitely interesting, that the gods from history dating back to Odin are still alive and well.  Having fallen from public eye and mind, they are reduced to almost nothing.  Meanwhile, the new things we worship, TV internet etc have become more powerful gods and there is a war brewing.<br /><br />The novel, however, is slowly plodding as it builds a very large web of characters.  It's part road trip, part fantasy and at times partly boring.  Mostly it's because there is a very slow build up of tension as Gaiman introduces characters, ploys and plots.  It isn't until the midpoint where something huge happens that the novel truly takes off.  But even when it takes off, it does it at its own pace.  The payoff at the end, however, is spectacular and ties up the story really well.<br /><br />Fans of Gaiman will enjoy this novel.  I think, for me, the problem was coming off such a high given by Neverwhere that whatever I read next couldn't possibly live up to it.  It's still a really good novel.  It's not his best but it's an enjoyable read and has some great commentary about out culture and religion.

Her ideas on setting a routine for baby each time they wake up worked wonderfully for us.  Babies like to know what is next so that they can fall into a pattern, a routine. If you read this book with an open mind and open heart to learning how to decipher your baby's cries or needs it can be helpful and a tool to learn about your baby. When i listen to death metal, i listen for music and if i could, i would abandon their vocals. If you loved the tantrum-driven antics of this self-titled then i guess you'll like self-titled.  So choose what you like, HARD AND HEAVY or MATURE AND HEAVY, lol! B0006L0LOS|1.0|What a nightmare.  Somebody pinch me and wake me up.  That's what I kept thinking while watching this movie, which turned out to be a truly painful experience.  And I'm not generally a conspiracy theorist, but after enduring \\"Catwoman,\\" directed by Pitof (who? who?), I'm convinced that someone (or ones) are out to sabotage the careers of both Halle Berry and Sharon Stone (not to mention Benjamin Bratt).  It's one thing to set out to make a \\"B\\" movie, but to waste such talent and beauty through sustained incompetence (yes, sustained, this movie wasn't filmed in a single day, was it?  Come to think of it, maybe it was...) is nothing short of criminal (cinematically speaking).    I do not like to dwell on the negative aspects of any film, and I always attempt to seek out the positive (even most bad movies have something good in them, though you often have to look hard and deep to find it), but in fairness to Halle Berry, it must be noted how badly the script, editing, graphics and visual f/x, choreography and the director-- especially the director-- failed her here.      This misfire shouldn't allow us to forget Berry's excellent performances in such films as \\"Introducing Dorothy Dandridge\\" and \\"Monster's Ball,\\" for which she deservedly was awarded an Oscar for Best Actress.  The extent of her talent is undeniable and evidenced by the fact that her presence alone can add the necessary spark and elevate the stature of movies like \\"Bulworth\\" and \\"Die Another Day.\\"  So the million dollar question is, how did she wind up in this embarrassment?  She (as well as the audience) deserves better.  Obviously, she put her trust in the wrong people this time around, and at the top of that list is the \\"director\\" of this mishmash, Pitof.    I guess the lesson here is that even a major star should be wary when approached with a project that's been placed in the hands of someone whose name sounds like one of those ridiculous vanity plates you try to figure out while sitting at a red light and staring at the car in front of you.  To put this as nicely as possible, Pitof (who? what does that MEAN?) didn't have a clue about what to do with this film, and especially with his actors.  How could this have happened?  He's given all the ingredients (Berry, Stone, Bratt, big budget) to make a prize winning cake and he turns out a lump unfit for consumption.    Add to Pitof's incompetence a laughably bad script (even the ability on the part of the viewer to suspend disbelief won't help with this one), bad editing and exceptionally poor computer graphics and visual f/x that look like something left over from the Stone Age of technology (when Catwoman is bounding and leaping about it has the appearance of an early generation video game; she looks more like a frog than a cat) you have a film that should be expunged from the resumes of everyone involved.      But, like I said, even a bad movie can have a high note if you look for it, which brings me to the only redeeming aspect of this film, the performance by Alex Borstein as Sally, one of Catwoman's co-workers.  Best known as the voice of Lois Griffin in TVs \\"The Family Guy,\\" Borstein has a charismatic presence that, within the context of this film at any rate, outshines even Berry and Stone.  Better off for all concerned had this movie been titled \\"Sally,\\" with Borstein given top billing and accordant screen time.    Unfortunately, too, for all concerned, \\"Catwoman\\" will enjoy it's full nine lives on the shelves of video stores everywhere.  Just keep in mind, when you come to this shelf, pick up \\"The Cat's Meow,\\"  \\"The Cat In the Hat,\\" \\"Cat People.\\" \\"Cat On A Hot Tin Roof,\\" or anything with \\"Cat\\" in the title that isn't followed by \\"Woman.\\"  Take it from me, you'll feel a lot better in the morning.

B000001FO4|3.0|They certainly had \\"the hair\\" but are they a hair band? The music here would suggest Cinderella isn't sure. There are touches of blues influence that suggest they'd like to evolve into Aerosmith territory, gritty AC/DC crunch, flashy pop metal choruses a la Jovi in spots, and the requisite \\"chick appeal\\" power ballads all 80s metal albums seemed to have.<br /><br />The band is vocalist/guitarist Tom Keifer, bassist Eric Brittingham, Jeff LaBar on rhythm guitar (was there a law that hair metal bands had to have a guy with a French name?), and Fred Coury adding \\"more cowbell\\" and skins. Rick Criniti pads the sound with B3, piano and synth for the power ballads. Musically, they're competent but there's a lot more \\"flash\\" than expertise.<br /><br />HIGHLIGHTS:<br />Road anthem \\"Gypsy Road\\" has a pretty decent hook and some clever lyrics for heavy metal (\\"I'm drivin' all night/Just to keep the rat in the race\\"). It sounds like a collision of AC/DC and Ratt. \\"Don't Know What you Got (Til' it's Gone)\\" is the one that gave them the hairband reputation and it's definitely a formula power ballad, though better than others of the ilk (Steelheart this means you...). \\"Second Wind\\" is one of the better ones musically with its shifting time signatures though the lyric's a shopworn \\"I can take what you dish out\\" metal number. After catching their (wait for it....) second wind, Keifer and company ride an instrumental jam out at the coda. Is it just me or does \\"If You Don't Like It\\" steal the beginning of \\"Eye of the Tiger\\"?  Once that section's over, it heads straight into Aerosmith territory. \\"Fire and Ice\\" could be an AC/DC outtake. It's straight-ahead bluesy power chords with Keifer in full Brian Johnson howl made.<br /><br />LOWS:<br />The title track musically is perfectly restrained anguish, like a slow Clapton blues number, but Keifer's screechy overblown vocal is way too cartoonish to make this heartfelt. It has all the subtlety of a daisy cutter bomb. \\"Coming Home\\" sounds like Brian Johnson fronting a generic Bon Jovi song. At 27, Keifer's already begging someone to \\"Take me Back\\" to help him recapture \\"yesterday's desire\\"? Isn't that a bit young to be a has-been?<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE:<br />It's OK but nothing you probably can't live without. If you're an AC/DC fan wanting something else for the collection, you may like enough of these tracks to pick it up. Better than most of the hair crowd, though.<br /><br />2 1/2 starseneric Bon Jovi song. At 27, Keifer's already begging someone to \\"Take me Back\\" to help him recapture \\"yesterday's desire\\"? Isn't that a bit young to be a has-been?    BOTTOM LINE:  It's OK but nothing you probably can't live without. If you're an AC/DC fan wanting something else for the collection, you may like enough of these tracks to pick it up. Better than most of the hair crowd, though.    2 1/2 stars
B0006L16N8|5.0|i've been listening to coldplay since parachutes. i'm a fan of that type of music. the most innovative, brilliant music comes from england. right now, the only band that can really compare to coldplay is radiohead. there's a lot of coldplay fans out there that jumped on the bandwagon after \\"clocks\\" - but there's also a lot of us who have been following this band form the get go, and like me, are happy to see this talented group of musicians finally make it big throughout the world. x+y is a fantastic album. it takes off from where rush of blood to the head ends and does a good job of mixing in classic parachutes era coldplay with rush of the blood and a newer direction, shwoing some great influences along the way, notably radiohead and echo and the bunnymen. speed of sound was a great first single but it barely etches the surface of what this album is all about. probably the strongest track on here is talk. it reminds one of a in my place and god put a smile upon your face. this is what coldplay does best: one part emotional digression, one part drum smashing, one part guitar driven rock. twisted logic is amazing. it is borderline neds/ok computer radiohead. chris martin's voice has never sounded better. and if you've ever seen coldplay live, then you know how great they really are in person - they are truly talented musicians. coldplay have suceeded because they are very good and they don't go on about it (see: oasis). another standout track is fix you, which is bound to become as infamous as the scientist. square one is a good song, but i don't think it should have opened the album. on rush of blood to the head, politik smashed into your ears the same way planet telex did on radiohead's the bends.  <br /> <br />overall a smashing album from a band that is destined to become the biggest talent of our generation. great work lads.

B000929AJQ|4.0|So... Nine Inch Nails is finally back. The mega-hyped, mega-delayed, mega-anticipated album With Teeth finally reached the public, and reviews so far have been mixed, to say the least. It has been called genius, a masterpiece, a rehash, so-so, and terrible. These differing opinions make sense because, as usual, With Teeth sounds nothing like any other NIN release. Personally, I admire the fact that Trent Reznor is not coasting on the same themes and sounds and is trying something new. As far the music on the album goes, it is, for the most part, strong, with some of the best tracks NIN has put down. Track by track is really the only way to dissect it, as the album is immensely varied (although focused). <br /> <br />All The Love In The World - For the first time ever, a NIN album doesn't open with a loud punch in the face. This very chilled-out song is excellent, driven by gentle techno beats until the end, when it reaches a dramatic sing-a-long. Awesome. <br /> <br />You Know What You Are - The heaviness starts here, with the sound of Dave Grohl assaulting his drum set with an almost death metal double bass rhythm. Although the song is angry and well put together, it just doesn't quite of the spark of \\"Wish\\" or \\"March Of The Pigs\\". It's a good track, but not one I'd imagine listening to again and again. <br /> <br />The Collector - A basic rock song, with basic NIN tricks and lyrics. The time signature is actually the reverse of \\"The Becoming\\", alternating measures of 7 and 6. The piano ending is a nice touch, but there isn't a whole lot amazing stuff going on. <br /> <br />The Hand That Feeds - A custom-made-for-radio rock song, it's like \\"The Collector\\" with a slick synth solo and a catchier chorus. Good, but not fantastic. <br /> <br />Love Is Not Enough - A mediocre first few tracks gives way to this, the worst song on the album. Completely bland and lifeless, with atypical Reznor lyrics, this is one of the few NIN songs I dislike entirely. Skip to the next one. <br /> <br />Every Day Is Exactly The Same - Thankfully, Reznor bounces back with one of the best songs on the album and of his carrer. A strong, vocal-based tune with a wonderful chorus. Will definately become a classic.  <br /> <br />With Teeth - This song is just weird. It lumbers along in a herky-jerky fashion through the verses, contains a gentle piano bridge, and includes the most outright ridculous chorus I've ever heard. Someone needs to take Trent's Metallica CD's away from him. <br /> <br />Only - Well, I don't think anyone in hell saw this song coming. The secong single is 80's, synthesized, super new wave. And it is GREAT. This beyond-creative track featured hilarious and poignent spoken word vocals, and a slap bass-meets-Billie Jean backdrop. Starting from here, the rest of the album is amazing. <br /> <br />Getting Smaller - The second really heavy song, this is much more exciting than YKWYA. The chorus explodes in a wall of noise, and the guitars and vocals are charged with energy. Very good. <br /> <br />Sunspots - A very dark, very cool song. It starts with low bass lines and a weird falsetto chorus, then explodes into a whole other section with the famous lyric, \\"Nothing can stop me now\\". After a strange nosie interlude, Trent finishes the song screaming a whole new part. Truly wicked. <br /> <br />The Line Begins To Blur - The last three songs kind of meld into a trilogy. This track, the first part, is almost perfect. It opens in classic NIN fashion, with pounding beats, strange electronic glitches, and Trent screaming his head off. Then the chorus does a complete 180, entering a melodic, surreal daydream. One of the best NIN songs ever. <br /> <br />Beside You In Time - This is the only song that really has any resemblance With Teeth's predecessor, The Fragile. It's very atmospheric and trippy, slowly building up steam. And towards the end, it explodes in a gigantic crunch of guitar and synth. A perfect blend of the epic rage of TLBTB and the gentle serenity of the next track. <br /> <br />Right Where It Belongs - Adding to the list of \\"Hurt\\" and \\"The Great Below\\", this peaceful ballad ends the album. The music blends a pretty piano with strange, almost mechanical keyboard sounds, showcasing NIN trademark of blending organic sound with electronic nuances. Trent sings a beautiful melody, and the song has a calm feel. Very good, although not quite in the league of the two aforementioned ballads. <br /> <br />So there you have it. With Teeth encompasses the personal songwriting and electronia of Pretty Hate Machine, the angst-fueled rock of Broken, the deranged industrial-pop of The Downward Spiral, and just a little of the sweeping epic drama of The Fragile. It doesn't rank as NIN's best achievment, and some songs range from mediocre to just plain bad. But for the most part, With Teeth is a successful attempt by a massively popular and accomplished artist to break his own mold and create a work of art unlike anything he has previously done. It begs the question of how will the next Nine Inch Nails release will sound, wich is set for release in 2016. Enjoy.
B0007GAERG|5.0|MARIAH THANK YOU..YOU HAVE MADE THE SUMMER FUN WITH THIS NEW ALBUM.
B0000026CM|5.0|In my opinion, this is by far the best TOTO album ever released. It has that big, late-80's sound that I love more than anything. And it has nothing but great songs - well written, performed, arranged and engineered. <br />But most importantly - it has so much TOTO on it! <br />All the boys are at their best on this album. For me as a big fan of Jeff Porcaro it's nice to hear so many different, wonderful grooves by him on one album. <br /> <br />This album is really extraordinary and deserves way more credit than it ever got. Songs like \\"Pamela\\", \\"Stop Loving You\\" and \\"These Chains\\" are among TOTO's best songs ever. <br /> <br />A true classic that ought to be on every music lover's CD shelf.

B0009ML238|4.0|When I got this CD and gave it a spin, I didn't find the band too entralling.  However, now, two weeks later, I can't stop listening to them and do think they have lots of potential.  This may also be because I think the music is a bit more difficult: lots of changes of tempo, rhythmically jazzy.  But it should be true of any good prog; so it's a truism.<br /><br />The band DOES sound very much like Dream Theater, as other reviewers have already noted.  Is it bad?  I personally do not think so.  I think it's quite a compliment to be compared to DT; if anything, it shows their musical virtuosity.  The vocals are quite similar as well (at times, also sound like ... Europe - remember them? :) Even when they DO sound like DT, it should be no complaint.  How many bands master that level of performance?<br /><br />In any case, I do think that this band is worth the attention.  It's funny, but you get their CD, listen to it, find it so DT-like and then you wonder what's their next album will be like; will they find their own sound/form?  Even if not, they're GOOD, the music is well-written and performed.<br /><br />Anyway, I am waiting for their next album, and hope it will be at least as good.  4 stars only for not being perfect...
B0006L16N8|4.0|This album is a balls to the wall epic mope fest for better or worse.  These guys are going for the rapturous stadium filling emotional slight of hand that lots of bands go for.  They seem to have found their influences in all the right places, Eno's 70's ambient work, Radioheads harsh prettiness, U2's embrace of embarassingly large songs.  They want you to really REALLY FEEL IT.  They succeed in parts.  Fix You gives Sigur Ros a brit-rock makeover, basically stealing Vaka's organ melody.  But as with too many Coldplay songs the music is there, the vocal melodies are there, and Chris Martin is given a big softball down the middle and he whiffs with his obvious lyrics.  It makes it hard to embrace the songs, but impossible to not at least somewhat enjoy it.  My favorites are A Message, Fix You, Square One, and the single.  There just isn't a song like Warning Sign or Amsterdam that hit hard on this album, so while its not hard to love the sound, its just not as affecting as before.
B0009I7NNA|2.0|I'll start out by eliminating any misconceptions people may have. I don't care that he doesn't scream anymore. I don't care that there aren't any chugga-chug breakdowns or blast beats. I don't like that crap either. But what they've replaced it with is just as bad. <br /> <br />This album is basically an attempt at taking European power metal and repackaging for the new American metal audience. This isn't anything new; ever since metalcore began to get stale and lose its credibility (which would be about 2 months after it first appeared), bands have been discarding the 'core' and trying more and more to show much they're in touch with the original metal styles. Problem is that unlike, say, 3 Inches of Blood, who took an old genre and breathed new life into it, these guys are just releasing sub-par, watered-down versions of the originals. There isn't a shred of originality, emotion, or inspiration on this album. The only people who would have the audacity to call it original are those who just recently threw away their Korn CD's and have never heard of Helloween, Stratovarius, or any of the other bands that they're poorly trying to pay tribute to. Not to mention that his voice obviously can't handle the range required for this style and sounds laughably like a 16-year old with a sinus problem. I heard that he had throat surgery, but does that mean we have to like the music out of sheer pity? It took all the kindness I had just to listen to a few songs without plugging my ears. <br /> <br />On another note: the Manowar-style lyrics on Waking the Fallen were just barely tolerable because I thought they might be tongue-in-cheek, but looking at this album, I'm beginning to doubt that. We get it, guys. You're tough, you're evil, you're so metal. Want a cookie? <br /> <br />This is an open letter to all metalcore-trying-to-be-real-metal bands out there: don't bother. 95% of your fanbase won't have any idea of the music you're trying to emulate anyway, and to the 5% that do, you'll just look silly. And really, there's a good reason 'true' metal died - it WAS stale and repetitive. Metalcore gave metal the kick in the pants that it needed, and just because THAT's gotten stale too doesn't mean you should go back to an older, even MORE stale genre. There are way too many 'retro' bands, and it's a tired gimmick. Let's move forward, not backwards. <br /> <br />So to sum up, don't get this, it's bad, terrible, bleh. If you really want retro done right, get 3 Inches of Blood's Advance and Vanquish or just go to the originals; otherwise wait for some actually NEW music.
B000929AJQ|4.0|Trent Reznor appeared to be painting himself into a corner, even as he achieved renown; his 1999 double-album The Fragile made no substantial changes to the industrial-collage style of his 1994 breakthrough The Downward Spiral, and then he vanished off the face of the earth, seemingly out of ideas. One might expect With Teeth, the first Nine Inch Nails album in six years, to be more of the same. But \\"All The Love In The World\\" opens it with sparse, skittering drums, suggesting that Reznor has finally derived some inspiration from all of those experimental techno bands that used to be on Nothing Records, and then, completely unexpectedly, takes off with a thumping house beat, as numerous vocal overdubs are layered on top of each other. Suddenly, Trent's comeback looks interesting.    With Teeth is what you might call a \\"stripped-down\\" album, one consisting of stomping beats, some chugging bass or grinding guitar playing simple rhythms, and the occasional burst of industrial noise. Many songs sound like they could be replicated pretty well on live instruments by a reasonably energetic three-piece. But if you think about it, the music always played a secondary role in Nine Inch Nails songs. Consider \\"Sin,\\" one of Reznor's earliest singles. I can't remember a single thing about what the music in that song sounded like, but I think I've got Reznor's clear, forceful diction on the lyrics memorized to perfection. The same goes for \\"Closer,\\" Reznor's unexpected big hit: the only musical aspect of that song that sticks out in my mind is the crack of the snare in the very beginning, but it's hard to forget Reznor's seething delivery of the verses, or his broken snarl in the chorus. Trent Reznor's persona was always at the centre of Nine Inch Nails, and his music always hinged on his vocal performances. So it is with this album. The weak songs are the ones where the lyrics don't have some kind of memorable rhythmic structure, like \\"The Collector,\\" where Trent just kind of drones, \\"I pick things up / I am a collector / And things, well things, they tend to accumulate.\\"    In general, the lyrics are not the album's strongest point. Their main theme is dehumanization, common subject matter in industrial music; people are compared to \\"insects\\" that \\"march along\\" or go \\"in step, in the line,\\" and several songs talk about obeying orders or doing what one is told. This bleak state of affairs, apparently, is the fault of a vague entity known only as \\"they,\\" e.g. \\"they figured me out,\\" \\"they won't let me leave,\\" \\"they got a way of reading my mind,\\" \\"I'll hide it behind something they won't look behind.\\" Trent's conflict with these mysterious \\"they\\" is described very vaguely, even by his standard, although it is possible to read \\"Every Day Is Exactly The Same\\" as a reference to the alcohol addiction that Reznor recently overcame. A few phrases, like \\"bleeding through,\\" \\"the line begins to blur,\\" and \\"I am still inside you,\\" are used in more than one song. Trent even lifts metaphors from previous Nine Inch Nails albums; the image of \\"The Collector\\" first appeared in \\"Ruiner\\" on The Downward Spiral, and \\"nothing can stop me now\\" in \\"Sunspots\\" was a recurring phrase on that same album.    What's new here is a greater sense of self-awareness, as if Trent is openly acknowledging the theatricality of his own image, simultaneously poking a bit of fun at it and confidently displaying his own charisma. Just listen to him belt \\"with-a teeth-a\\" in the title track. Sure, he's just saying two words over and over, and they probably don't mean anything, but his voice has a swagger to it that just wasn't there before. Elsewhere, he yells \\"hey,\\" \\"uh-huh,\\" and \\"flip-flop-flip-flop-flip,\\" croons \\"hoo-hoo\\" and \\"she turns me on\\" in an impressive falsetto, and follows up a typical line like \\"I want to kill away the rest of what's left\\" with the addendum, \\"and I do, yes I do.\\" As a result, the album never feels heavy at all, despite containing plenty of distorted guitars and screaming. It feels fun. Even \\"You Know What You Are?\\" and \\"The Line Begins To Blur,\\" the two heaviest and most dissonant songs, sound almost light-hearted in parts, due to the groovy keyboard break in the former and the \\"ooh-ooh\\" ending in the latter.    Reznor's newfound good cheer really becomes evident on \\"Only.\\" This song has formless spoken-word lyrics, and Trent delivers them in a conversational manner, patiently explaining, \\"well, you might say I'm losing focus, kind of drifting in the abstract.\\" Then, when he repeats, \\"I just made you up to hurt myself,\\" it sounds like he's making up the song on the spot and can't think of a next line, so he just concludes, \\"and it worked, yes it did!\\" But this is an intended effect; in reality, the song is tight and finely crafted, with a snappy club beat and some of that Peter Hook action on the bass. The simple music creates a catchy framework for Trent's voice, like it does many times on With Teeth; the album's midsection contains a string of similar-sounding but undeniably awesome songs, like \\"Getting Smaller,\\" a potential alternative radio hit which takes a fast tempo and a brief counter-riff played after every line of lyrics, and rides them into a splendid sing-along chorus, or \\"Sunspots,\\" which is brought to a rousing conclusion by the sudden appearance of a blaring synthesizer, or \\"The Hand That Feeds,\\" which tweaks the lyrical themes a bit to add a topical air.    So, With Teeth is much better than The Fragile. It is also probably more listenable and accessible than The Downward Spiral. But it will never have the cultural impact of that album, nor will it ever be the soundtrack of choice for the adolescent emotional crisis of a large and devoted following, like Pretty Hate Machine was. Even so, it's good to have Trent back.

B000002UJQ|5.0|After an okay debut album (but still stellar effort as it was a debut, not only for the band, but also for the mini-genre they have carved out), Radiohead releases The Bends, which is a mind-bending album which many, including myself, consider a classic album. Then, they release OK Computer, and this album follows just nicely. It also provides a good transition between The Bends and Amnesiac as they blend the classic, guitar-oriented rock sound with the new-age, electronic rock sound to follow. If you are a new fan of Radiohead, welcome to their world. I would say to start with The Bends, and then buy this album. If you are a Radiohead fan and don't own this album, then you're light years behind. This album is very important to understanding the mood and feelings behind Thom Yorke's seemingly incomprehensible lyrics. The tone of the album is reminiscent of Pink Floyd (as is a lot of their stuff, though you don't have to be a fan of Floyd to appreciate this band) in that it is very moody. Yorke paints a world in which he is seemingly lost, and that is the fast-paced, dog-eat-dog world of corporate conformity. A world he so desperately wants to break free from and destroy. In some songs he feels constricted by this world. In others, he completely sattirizes that world. Overall, a great album with a powerful meaning, but certainly an album you have to be patient with to fully gain the value from. If you're just into good tunes and melodies, then only a few songs will appeal to you. If you're into artfully designed rock music, this is the perfect album (and band) for you.   Favorite song: \\"Let Down\\"

B00099BPOW|3.0|This edition of Aida was formerly on 3 cd's and sold for about $50.00 dollars but now it has been put on two cd's and sells for bargain price.  There is no libretto included but there is a detailed track by track synopsis.  The booklet inside is sparse with no photos and you will only find the track details and a listing of the characters/vocalists with a final page devoted to recording information.  This production was recorded in digital stereo in the early 80's but no remastering has been done.    The sound is PRETTY GOOD with a little congestion in the louder passages and lacking somewhat in presence.  I personally didn't feel the great sense of atmosphere or splendour that i felt with the Decca Karajan version and Abbado conducts with attention to detail but could use more dramatic bite and emotional abandon in CERTAIN moments.  Abbado's conducting is not VERY passionate and is a little more on the intellectual side.  I would have found the orchestral aspect a lot more compelling and affecting if Abbado could have loosened up a bit more but he does have his moments.  Domingo is in his best voice technically and he handles the characterization of Radames passionately and effectively.  Ricciarelli is a vocalist i have always liked especially in lighter roles such as Mimi in \\"La Boheme\\" but she has moments of strain and impure tone in her performance as Aida.  It is a role that is very hard on her at times and when she has to hit those testy high notes like in \\"O patria mia\\" she sounds very strained,thinned out,and pitchy.  It's painful to hear because she handles the characterization so well with extremely eloquent phrasing giving a lot of meaning and passion to the words that she is singing.  The Mezzo Elena Obraztsova who portrays Amneris also has a voice that is challenging to the listener.  Her voice has a unpleasant thick globby sound to it and her vibrato has a wobble that at times is linked to faulty pitch especially during challenging high notes.  This gets in the way of concentrating on her characterization which she does well.  Leo Nucci plays Amonasro very effectively with a full sharp dramatic grasp on the characterization and fine powerful singing.   The rest of the cast does a fine job as well but i just felt that this Aida fell short of greatness and wasn't a compelling experience.   I base this opinion in comparrison to the Karajan/Tebaldi Decca version, The Levine Domingo Millo digital version, the Mehta Corelli EMI version, the Gigli Serafin Naxos Historical version,  and the Bjorling Perlea Rca version.  All of these are all in all better choices even though the Bjorling and Gigli versions are in mono sound but the casts are superb with the Bjorling set having a flaw in the conductor/orchestra team but they are still acceptable.  This particular Aida is a GOOD bargain and if you love the vocalists than this might be your deal but there is better.  I hope this review was helpful to you and happy opera hunting.    Oscar F.

B000002GQE|5.0|1967 is a famous year in the history of popular music, but when music writers refer to the numerous classic albums that came out during those twelve months, they often forget about the most groundbreaking one of the lot - Days of Future Passed.  With this album, the Moody Blues not only successfully relaunched their flagging career, but also created what is arguably the first true concept album.  The record also brought together the rock and classical music worlds for the first time, and helped to kick-start what would become known as prog rock.    So much for the album's historical significance - the question is, does it still sound good today? The answer is an emphatic yes, thanks to the high quality of the band's music and the skilful way their songs were blended in with the orchestral interludes provided by Peter Knight and the London Festival Orchestra.  With Days of Future Passed, the Moodies hit upon the unique, lush musical style that would carry them to huge success, and some of the best examples of that style can be found on this album, which takes the form of a simple journey through one man's day.      The most outstanding songs, of course, are by lead singer/guitarist Justin Hayward.  Hayward was only 20 when this album was recorded, but with Tuesday Afternoon and the unforgettable Nights in White Satin (arguably the greatest love song ever), he announces himself as a brilliant songwriter - incredibly, he would continue composing songs of a similar standard for decades to come.  One of the band's strengths in these early days, however, was that every member contributed songs, and the others all get their chance to shine.  Keyboardist Mike Pinder provides the sublime Dawn is a Feeling, featuring a typically lovely Hayward vocal, and also the haunting Sun Set, while throughout the album he also demonstrates his mastery of the mellotron, the keyboard whose ethereal sounds would become the Moodies' trademark throughout their \\"classic 7\\" albums.  Flautist Ray Thomas also shows his somewhat underrated songwriting talent with the child-like Another Morning and the more rocking Twilight Time, which demonstrates that the Moodies were more than capable of giving their music a harder edge when they felt like it.  Bass player John Lodge also contributes, and his haunting Evening (Time to Get Away) is one of the album's highlights, although his other offering, the rocking Peak Hour, sounds a bit out of place with the other tracks.  Finally, drummer Graeme Edge commences the tradition he would maintain over the next few albums of contributing pieces of spoken poetry.  Listened to in isolation, these can sound a bit dated and cringeworthy, but when you listen to the whole album they fit in unobtrusively, providing the record with a beginning and an end.  The great thing about Days of Future Passed is that it is a complete listening experience, and the individual tracks flow almost seamlessly into each other.    In short, this album is a true classic, and one any music lover should own.  It also marked the start of a golden era for the Moodies, who would produce many more great albums over the next few years.
