B00027JYLC|5.0|Back in vogue after being shunned and even banned at the time of its release, Freaks is a daring look into the lives of unusual circus performers in an era 75 years lost and gone.  Having been made in 1932, you won't be seeing any special effects or phenomenal feats, but what you will see is the best collection of freak show performers Hollywood could gather at the time.<br /><br />The plot is fairly simple.  Beautiful trapeze artist Cleopatra (Olga Baclanova) toys with midget Hans (Harry Earles) until she discovers that Hans has a great deal of money.  The gold-digging Cleopatra, together with boyfriend/strongman Hercules (Henry Victor) plots to capture Hans' little heart and steal him away from fianc&eacute; Frieda (Daisy Earles).<br /><br />Cleopatra achieves her goal, capturing the sweet and gullible Hans into marriage, but at their wedding feast among the circus' more peculiar acts, Cleopatra becomes drunk and her malicious nature explodes.  The freaks, alerted to Cleopatra's snaky underbelly, ally themselves with Hans who has mysteriously fallen ill.<br /><br />Coming to Hans' aid, the circus freaks corner Cleopatra in her schemes, catching her red-handed with poison in her hand, and chase her out into a bitter rainstorm to her doom.<br /><br />Let's face it, the real attraction to Freaks is the abnormal conformation of the human actors involved.  Prince Randian, the Living Torso; Daisy and Violet Hilton, the Siamese Twins; Johnny Eck, the half-man; Frances O'Connor and Martha Morris, the armless girls; Peter Robinson, the Human Skeleton; Elvira and Jenny Lee Snow, the microcephalics, or \\"Pinheads\\"; Elizabeth Green, the Bird Girl, and of course Schlitze, the happy-go-lucky \\"pinhead\\" who lived until 80 years of age in real life.<br /><br />Not being professional actors, these performances are slightly wooden, but the group works so well together that you should be able to overlook the amateur acting.  For what little Browning had to work with in regards to sets, the scenery and background was carried out quite well.  The photography is not top quality, even for 1932, but overall the film is more \\"good\\" than it is \\"bad\\".  I feel that it is an important film, especially to anyone who enjoys modern day horror.  Freaks, after all, was the birth of abnormality in horror, bringing in the human condition rather than werewolves and vampires.<br /><br />Once you have watched the movie, turn to the Special Features.  I do not usually tout special features on DVD's, but the ones with Freaks are must see.<br /><br />First is the Special Message Prologue, that should have played before the movie also.  Next, the movie with commentary by author David Skal.  Third is the best feature, called Freaks: The Sideshow Cinema.  This is an interview type commentary with author David Skal, Sideshow Performer/Historian/Author Todd Robbins, Sideshow Performer/Historian Johnny Meah, Actor and Little Person Mark Povinelli, and Actor and Little Person Jerry Maren.  This special feature is as entertaining as the movie itself, and is a \\"not to be missed\\" feature.  It includes segments revealing the private lives of some of the sideshow actors involved in the film.<br /><br />As a side note, during one of the still shots, take a look at the size of that 1930's movie camera.  It's the size of a compact car...almost!<br /><br />Freaks is a DVD that every horror aficionado should own, and watch more than once.  The subtleties of horror are all there in their embryonic stages, made available by presenting real flesh rather than skin bondo.  And yet, these people were portrayed as happy individuals, living a communal lifestyle inside the warm comfort of each other.  A real community, not remotely like Hillary Clinton's \\"grasping at election straws\\" communities.<br /><br />Lots to study in this piece, but lots to enjoy also.  Pop some old fashioned popcorn in oil on your gas stove, get yourself a coke and put some maraschino cherries in it, then sit back andenjoy this long lost treasure.  Enjoy!hen sit back and enjoy this long lost treasure.  Enjoy!  <br />

B00006AW2M|4.0|Quite possibly the most maligned album in their career, 'Satanic Majesties' has definitely been better appreciated over the last thirty-eight years then when it was first released in December 1967. Still, there is more than one track on here that smacks of psychedlic overindulgence. '67 was a very trying year for the Stones as most fans know. Jagger, Richards and Jones all faced drug charges (Jagger's was absurd, has anybody been been busted for dramamine????)which were later quashed after a scathing editorial in the London Times, but the future did look pretty bleak. Experimentation continued and the year long acid trip which was started by January's 'Between the Buttons' was further explored by the \\"We Love You\\" single and the 'SMR' at the conclusion of a very trying year. As for the lp itself, several songs deserve honorable mention: classics such as \\"She's a Rainbow\\", \\"2000 Light Years from Home\\", \\"Citadel\\" (love that booming guitar sound!), \\"2000 Man\\" (a true lost classic, later covered by KISS) and \\"The Lantern\\". A misstep? Probably and the inevitable 'Sgt. Pepper' comparisons may be warranted but this has to be recognized as a band under trying times trying to stretch out their sound. The Stones were able to bounce back from the lackluster response for this album and for the next five to six years would create a body of work that would not only restore their supergroup status but could be considered one of the greatest runs of brilliance in the history of rock music. As for 'Satanic Majesties', \\"and my kids(critics? fans?) they just don't understand me at all.\\"

B000002H6C|5.0|For quite a long time, Metallica's \\"Master Of Puppets\\" was my absolute favorite metal album. I believed that nothing could possibly top it. That all changed when a friend first lent me \\"...And Justice For All\\" two years ago. <br /> <br />The opener, \\"Blackened\\", simply blew me away, and the pace kept going with the title track and \\"Eye Of The Beholder\\". Up until that point, I had been thinking that it was pretty great, but not quite \\"Master Of Puppets\\" caliber. And then I reached \\"One\\". <br /> <br />What can I say? It's my favorite Metallica song, and to this day, one of my top five favorite metal songs, period. It begins as a beautiful ballad, then slowly builds up into one of the most crushing thrash songs that the world has ever seen. If you ever need to describe thrash metal to someone through one song, that song is \\"One\\". <br /> <br />The next three songs are also great thrash, and definitely not worth skipping. But then we reach (IMHO) the greatest metal instrumental ever, \\"To Live Is To Die\\". This stirring tribute to Cliff Burton, Metallica's former bassist, is emotional, epic, and heavy all at once. <br /> <br />So after all this awesome metal, I was thinking, \\"How can the last song live up to all of this? There is no better Metallica closer than 'Damage Inc.', and i'm not sure that even that song is worthy.\\" But \\"Dyers Eve\\" is definitely worthy. This is another one of my favorite Metallica songs, and it's a great way to end this majestic album. <br /> <br />So my recommendation? Buy it now. Whether you're a fan of old or new Metallica, \\"...And Justice For All\\" will not disappoint.

Then, I'm a hardcore fan of Zep, and when I listen this album after some large time, this drives me an mistycal enviroment, etereal and atmospherical scope. It's one of the few discs that I put one and other time again. And for me it's the BEST ROCK BAND OF ALL TIME tied with PINK FLOYD.    Combining the visceral power and intensity of hard rock with the finesse and delicacy of British folk music, Led Zeppelin redefined rock in the Seventies and for all time. They were as influential in that decade as the Beatles were in the prior one. Their impact extends to classic and alternative rockers alike. Then and now, Led Zeppelin looms larger than life on the rock landscape as a band for the ages with an almost mystical power to evoke primal passions. The combination of Jimmy Page's powerful, layered guitar work, Robert Plant's keening, upper-timbre vocals, John Paul Jones' melodic bass playing and keyboard work, and John Bonham's thunderous drumming made for a band whose alchemy proved enchanting and irresistible. \\"The motto of the group is definitely, `Ever onward,'\\" Page said in 1977, perfectly summing up Led Zeppelin's forward-thinking philosophy.    At the dawn of the new millennium, Led Zeppelin placed second only to the Beatles in terms of record sales, having sold 84 million units.     Led Zeppelin IV IS THE FOURTH BEST-SELLING ALBUM IN HISTORY, having sold more than 22 MILLI0N COPIES, and FOUR OTHER ALBUMS by the band - Physical Graffiti, Led Zeppelin II, Houses of theHoly and Led Zeppelin - also rank among the all-time top 100 best-sellers. Fittingly, Led Zeppelin is tied with the Beatles (five apiece) for the most albums on that esteemed list - a mark of both bands' impact. In their ceaseless determination to move music forward, Led Zeppelin carved out an indelible place in rock history.     There is not doubt, Led Zeppelin isn't only a great ROCK BAND, is one of the most influencial style of music, and philosophy into the lifes of several generations. THEIR INDUCTION IN ROCK AND ROLL HALL OF FAME IN 1995 IS NOT A CASUALITY, it's only a recognize of the scope of their exceptional work. LED ZEPPELIN is a Living Loving Leyend.

B000002O51|3.0|NOTICE: If you do not have this record, do not buy it without finishing reading this review.    THIRD STAGE is not near as good a record as the band's previous two (DON'T LOOK BACK and BOSTON). The main reason for this is more than likely that the band is gone. Brad Delp (mainly lead and harmony vocals) and Tom Scholtz (mainly guitar) were the only band members left at that point, leaving Boston in a dark spot; Tom Scholtz covered most of the music (shining a light on his almost overly-apparent talent), but he overdid it - far too many overdubs (even for Boston) were added, and more than 80% of the record's drums are recreated through keyboards (drum simulators, if you may). There is hardly any natural sound; the acoustic twelve-string guitars are essential to the album. Without them, this album would be blow-dried, air-conditioned claustrophobia wrapped into a disc.    THIRD STAGE gets an rounded 3 stars from me, the result of disappointment and a reverse effect: certain things can 'grow on you' over time, but this seemed to 'grow off me' over time. It might seem great when you buy it, but that will change.    DO NOT EXPECT THE BOSTON FROM THE 70'S - YOUR EXPECTATIONS WILL FAIL YOU!

1400082773|3.0|Please, don't get me wrong, I loved this book.  Obama's style and matter-of-fact realism is both refreshing and, at times, inspiring.  The only reason why this book isn't 4+ stars, is because of the expectations that this book leads the reader to believe.  <br /> <br />What I mean is that by reading the summary and back cover, the reader expects to experience a man torn between two cultures and belonging to neither.  And while Obama does clearly illustrate his trepidation with associating himself with either culture, from the very beginning we learn that Obama, for all intents and purposes, held his black heritage in a different regard.  He was not torn so much as distraught, growing up in a 'white' world unfamiliar with his black background.  From reading this book, the reader does not get the sense of Obama'a sturggle with his white roots.  The story is rather a search for answers on how to live as a black man in a white world.  I believe that Obama missed the chance of opening the doors to a wholely different and misunerstood world of children of differing cultures.  In this 'melting pot' that we call America, there is a constant struggle between race and ethnicity and Obama could have set himself up as an educator, a leader of those who had no home.  Yet, from the beginning, Obama was at home in his black heritage, but he just was looking for the key.

0684800713|4.0|This novel is Hemingway's earliest. It contrasts starkly with his last novel with only two human characters and one animal protagonist/antagonist (The Old Man and The Sea). It narrates the story of aimless young men and women touring France and Spain. The narrator is the observer of his friends destinies. All are in love with a flirtatious girl, but the most unlikely one (the narrator) wins in the end. This novel is beautiful for its picturesque descriptions of countryside and bull-fighting.

(Both of the roommates ended up borrowing my set to show their families, who I believe later bought the DVDs for themselves.) <br /> <br />As for the show itself? Amazing. I haven't seen enough TV to call it the best show ever, but it's certainly my favorite, and from what I've seen, it's extremely rare that shows deliver as well and as consistently as these 14 episodes do. Effects, score, lighting, costumes, sets, acting, story, and characterization are all top-notch. <br /> <br />The extras are also well-done and demonstrate the obvious love that the cast and crew have for the show. The commentaries are full of information (such as that one of my few caveats with the show -- that at the end of some of the episodes, everything's wrapped up a bit too neatly and happily -- was actually Fox's insistence), as well as stories from the set and lots of joking around. <br /> <br />Go see Serenity in September. It's really, really good. And you'll be able to enjoy it whether or not you've seen Firefly. <br /> <br />But if you'd like to get to know the characters a bit better beforehand, or if you'd just like to watch 15 hours of great television, check out Firefly. <br />If you want to see it before taking the plunge, it'll be airing on SciFi Channel on Fridays at 7 Eastern starting July 22. You might also check your local library or video store. <br />Now's a good time to buy the DVDs though since their price has dropped somewhere between 5 and 10 dollars from what it was before. <br />Enjoy the show, curse its premature ending, and have fun on September 30th at the movie!
037571457X|5.0|I heard about this book through a friend of mine who went to a book signing by Marjane Satrapi in town recently. The book mainly deals with the author's childhood years going in Iran shortly before, during and right after the Revolution. It was interesting to see how she developed her progressive views from her Communist parents and other relatives like her grandmother and uncle who defied the restrictive Iranian government. The book is also impressive because you get a first hand view of what it was really like to be a woman in that society. I think I learned more about the Iranian Revolution, or at least an alternative view, from reading this book than from all those years in school. If you are looking for a pro-American/pro-Western Iranian point of view, you are likely not to find much of it in this book, as it talks a lot about negatively about Western policies towards Iran's oil industry and Western involvement in Iraq. The drawings are amazing. I felt like Satrapi's life vividly came to life to me and told her story more clearly to me, which made to book even better.

0375422889|5.0|This book picks up where Persepolis left off, when Marji's parents send her to Vienna to escape the traditionalist Iranian regime. This sequel is equally as impressive. This deals more with how others, in this case Europeans, identify her as \\"other.\\" Marji always felt like an \\"outsider\\" or a \\"Third-Worlder\\" as she had a hard time relating sometimes to her white friends. From being a homeless drug addict for a brief time to finding out one her first loves was gay to becoming an aerobics teacher, Marji definitely goes through more things in her short time than most people do in a lifetime. I was thoroughly impressed with the author's storytelling abilities, which were sad, thought-provoking and comical, which made it hard for me to even put down the book. It was really great to read a book about a Iranian feminist who lives her life the way she wants to live it. I was impressed by this book because the Western media gives the impression that all Muslim women are helpless, when in fact as one read this book, Muslim women are empowered and taking control of their lives.

B00005JNSK|4.0|Almost everyone remembers \\"Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory\\" fondly.  It so effortlessly captured that sense of childlike innocence and wonder of seeing an impossible dream come to pass.  And if \\"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory\\" doesn't quite reach that same level of wonderment, it is still a strange and wonderful ride, led by the always visually incomparable Tim Burton and his favorite foil Johnny Depp.  The film focuses, of course, on Willy Wonka (Depp) a brilliant but reclusive candy maker searching for an heir through an elaborate contest.  Five lucky children will discover a golden ticket hidden with their wonka bars, meaning they will tour Wonka's magical factory, not knowing that Wonka's sugary empire will be bequeathed to one of them. Most moviegoers will know the story by heart, but Burton, Depp and screenwriter John August put such a fresh spin on the tale that audiences will not mind seeing the old, familiar faces another time. <br />  <br />One of those faces has always served as the crutch of the story: the well-meaning and earnest Charlie Bucket (a superb Freddie Highmore).  He is not strong or fast or tall, but he has a good heart, formed by the loving relationship with his family.  Much of the film's heart is found in the terrific rapport that Charlie has with his family, that include Helena Bonham Carter as his soft-spoken mother, Noah Taylor as his hard-working father, David Morris as the cantankerous Grandpa George and David Kelley as the feisty but big-hearted Grandpa Joe.   The early scenes featuring Charlie and his family are the best of the whole film, giving plenty of hearty laughs and strong  characters.  They all eagerly watch as four of Wonka's golden tickets are found by selfish and undeserving children before they joyously witness Charlie get his hands on the last one by sheer luck. <br />  <br />Soon Charlie and his grandfather head to Wonka's factory with the other winners and tour the amazing and impeccably concieved ChocolateFactory.  Alex McDowells' colorful production design and Phillipe Rousselot's vivid cinematography are wonders unto themselves.  But more importantly it's here that we get our first good look at Depp as Wonka.  His performance is a radical departure from Gene Wilder's original portrayal.  Depp's Wonka is self-exile from society due to problems with his dentist daddy (Christopher Lee) disowning him for being a choclatier.  Depp's performance works a little too well at first.  He's distant from the gaggle touring his factory but he's also a a little removed from the audience, who are bound to be caught off-guard by his overtly weird turn as Wonka.  But give Depp and Burton time.  The character grows and starts to emerge from his shell as the movie goes along, aided by great moments of off-kilter humor and Burton's extraordinary visuals, leading to a sweetly satisfying conclusion that never comes off syrupy.
0785787135|5.0|I thought this book was wonderfully written, and MZB truly captures the essence of her characters.  It is so fascinating to read about a time when Christianity was not yet dominant, and the process by which it came to be so. The thing that most endeared me to the novel was the way in which Avalon was brought so vividly and beautifully to life in my mind and heart. The book made me believe that somewhere out there, Avalon still exists, a place full of magic and mystery, untouched by the hand of time.  It is both an inspirational story and a melancholy one; highlighting triumph and failure alike.   <br /> <br />The book certainly divulges from the mainstream of \\"accepted\\" Arthurian legend, but the turns that it takes are believable and well thought-out.  If you are looking for a story of the infallible goodness and bravery of Arthur and his knights, this book is probably not for you, since more times than not, the men appear weak and vulnerable, easy prey for the women that control them.  However, if you are looking for a new perspective, the women are written not as the evil downfall of men, but as real people with feelings, motives, strength, and sorrow.  I found it very refreshing. <br /> <br />My least favorite aspect of the book was that Merlin was written as two characters, the first being more of a traditional Merlin figure named Taliesin, and after he dies, his successor Kevin is a deformed man with no loyalty to Avalon.  Merlin is, to me, one of the pinnacle figures of Arthurian legend, a wise and benign mentor to Arthur, and I did not enjoy him being sidelined and weakened in this way.

B000980GRU|4.0|Will Smith is a cute, funny, and charismatic actor who has charm to spare. It is, therefore, surprising that Hollywood has never before cast him as the lead in a  romantic comedy. I doubt that this oversight will occur again, as Mr. Smith takes to the genre like a duck takes to water and makes it his own. His seemingly effortless, laidback style of acting strikes pay dirt as the romantic lead in this film. I am sure that Hollywood has now taken notice that Will Smith has what it takes to be the lead in a romantic comedy.<br /><br />Will Smith is cast in the role of Alex \\"Hitch\\" Hitchens, a young, suave, successful, sophisticated, smooth talker who has devised a career out of his ability to show even the most clumsy and shy, geeky guy how to get hitched to the woman of his dreams. He takes on clients whom he then  coaches in the mysteries of finding one's way into the heart of a beloved, but seemingly unattainable, woman.<br /><br />Our erstwhile dating consultant is hired by Albert (Kevin James),  a chubby, earnest, tongue-tied accountant, who has fallen for one of his firm's own clients, socialite-heiress Allegra Cole (Amber Valleta). She is a trophy type of woman who, one would think, would not even given Albert a second look. Under Hitch's careful coaching, however, even our unlikely, lovesick accountant seems to be on the road to  true love.<br /><br />Of course, them that can, do, while them that can't, coach, and Hitch is no exception. While he can successfully coach his clients to attain the love of their lives, Hitch runs into a whole host of problems in his life when dealing with his own romance. It appears that he has fallen for the gorgeous Sara (Eva Mendes), a local gossip columnist. Despite his ability to ensure that the path of true love runs smoothly for others, he himself runs into many roadblocks and bumps in the road.<br /><br />Will Smith is simply terrific in the role of \\"Hitch\\", playing the role with insouciant charm. His likeability quotient can't get much higher, and he certainly infuses the role with his effortless charm and humor. Hollywood would be remiss in not casting Will Smith in other romantic comedies, as he is such an ingratiating performer that the viewer cannot help but fall in love with him.  As his love interest, Eva Mendes is certainly a gorgeous leading lady, although her character is not always likable. Still, she makes the most of her role as the feisty Sara, and I look forward to seeing her in more films.<br /><br />I totally enjoyed seeing Kevin James in the film. He is the star of the long-running, hit television series, \\"The King of Queens\\", a show that I love and wish would run forever.  I was not disappointed by his transition to the big screen, as I really enjoyed his performance. He is simply a big, cuddly, teddy bear sort of guy that you can't help but love, which helps make his on-screen pairing with Amber Valleta believable. They are simply adorable together. Amber Valleta  successfully infuses her character, Allegra Cole,  with a certain vulnerability that makes her very likable.<br /><br />Kudos also go to director, Andy Tennant, whose deft direction contributes to the success of this film. This is a well-written, well-acted romantic comedy that is highly enjoyable. Co-stars Will Smith and Kevin James have great chemistry in the film and are excellent foils for each other. I would love to see them paired together in a buddy movie, as I think that they would be sensational.  Fans of romantic comedies, however, would be well-advised to see this film. 0887307280|5.0|Over the past ten years or so (being an owner of several part-time businesses during that span) I have read many books and listened to many people about how to run a business.  While there are many worthy advisors (and many that are not), Gerber tells it like no other.  He very successfully relates his vision of business in such a way that allows the reader to develop one's own business related vision based on solid principles that have been time-tested.  For all that I have read and heard about formulating business models and building business plans for my endevors, I have never really understood what that meant or how to begin to go about it in any personally relevant or meaningful way - until now.  Steven Covey said, \\"Begin with the end in mind.\\"  Gerber, as no other, has helped me to get a clear picture - a real picture - of that end, as I truly want to envision it.  He has also given me a freshly relevant outline of the building process.  I can say, for the first time, that I finally have a solid vision, and a firm *foundation* on which to build.      I usually don't buy books anymore.  I go to the library.  But this one I bought, and I don't regret it.  I want it handy.  I will soon be reading it again, taking notes.

1416500189|4.0|My friend Ron has a Chinese girlfriend. If he marries her as planned, she will be his third wife, each of which has been progressively younger than he.  <br /> <br />So, it is ironic that he would have recommended this book to me. The story concerns a subsistence farmer named Wang Lung, and follows the arc of his life from the morning he rises to go claim his new wife until his waning days. Along his dramatic path, he changes from nave farmer who looks on in horror at the excess of the Chinese ruling classes to one who, with his own wealth secured, exhibits the same behaviors as the wealthy he once so despised.  <br /> <br />It's a great book, rightly considered a classic, and what makes the book even more fascinating is to consider just how recently the events described were occurring in China. The book was published in 1935 and describes life in China in the early 20th century. There are no doubt Chinese citizens still alive who vividly remember this period though it would seem to describe a way of life that passed away long ago. The world the author describes, with peasant serfs working the land while the ruling gentry slowly wastes away from over consumption of life's luxuries, passed away in Europe long before this book was published or the author was even born. China, it would seem, has taken a long time catching up to the West in terms of the condition of its poorest people.  <br /> <br />Deep in the background of the book are the upheavals that came with the arrival of the industrial age, including the arrival of the railroad, and in the case of China, the social revolution that later formed the government. Before this, most people were like Wang Lung, who lived just as his father did, back through the generations. The primary concern of such people was their crops because if the land failed to produce, they and everyone they knew would starve. Such was the life of peasants everywhere at one time.  <br /> <br />I have the `enriched classic' version from Pocket Books, which provides detailed biographical information about the author, Pearl Buck. Buck was the child of Christian missionaries who took her to China where she presumably witnessed first hand many of the events described in the book. The notes also state the Buck's mother renounced her faith at the end of her life, and that Buck was a leading voice of feminism at the time of her death in 1973.  <br /> <br />If Buck's mother witnessed the events described in the book, and if she in fact renounced her faith, it was surely the brutality of the living conditions of the Chinese poor that swung her to the pessimism that destroys a faith in a living and just God. The book vividly describes the condition of the poor as well as the pathetic decadence of the pampered wealthy. Those who have witnessed the worst in humanity, like so many Europeans who lived through the world wars, sometimes can no longer reconcile the wickedness of people and the brutality of nature with the idea of an all knowing and loving God. Such may have been the fate of Buck's mother.  <br /> <br />And yet it is the overwhelming lack of any active faith in a God that stands out in the book. Early on, Wang Lung burns a few pieces of incense to a local earth god that has been made of sticks and paper, and he worries about evil spirits, but there isn't anywhere in his life or in the story an organized church that protests on the part of the poor, admonishes the rich, influences authorities and demands that they act in a moral and responsible way. It is the sheer lack of any voice of moral authority that allows the nature of humanity, which is craven, to dominate. Without such moral guidance, he acts in the same degrading manner as his competitors as soon as he is empowered to do so. His children grow soft and petulant, yet due to his planning and their control of the land, they remain rich.  <br /> <br />Of course, when the book was published, Buck couldn't know what was about to happen. In 1949, thecommunists finally consolidated power over the entire nation and wealthy land owners like Wang Lung were forced into collective farms. The entire system that produced the rise and fall of local landowners was eradicated; all fell together as the state took control of private assets. This was a disaster from a productive standpoint, and so to control the swelling population, the government limited every family to one child, which made the acquisition of more and younger wives a moot point.  <br /> <br />This brings me back to my friend, Ron. I love my friend and I wish him the best, but Ron, like Wang Lung, has no faith and is following his want and will on to a fresh woman, just like Wang Lung. Ron is economically empowered to get a new younger wife, and in China, he has found a willing party. The book describes the process of acquiring a young wife, and it is primarily economic; women are purchased. I've suggested to Ron that the economic disparity between he and his fiance is driving the deal, but he laughs it off. He's having fun, at least for now. The book clearly reasons that relationship entanglements beyond his first wife weakened Wang Lung, and made him unhappy and an object of pity in his old age. If Ron escapes a similar fate, I will be quite surprised.   <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />  <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />
B000002G87|5.0|Every artist has a career album and this is Eric Clapton's.  This CD is not only his personal best but one of the All-time Rock classics.  The album is primarily blues and has alot of electric slide guitar on it. This album was put together in the studio over a period of months. The sessions were very long and often they would sleep right there in the recording studio.  Duane Allman plays much of the slide on the CD.  This CD includes the classics \\"Bell Bottom Blues, Key to the Highway, Have you ever loved a woman. Layla and a very strong version of the Jimi Hendrix classic \\"Little Wing\\". There is not a bad song on the entire CD. This will prove to be Eric Claptons' finest hour and still holds up to the test of time.  This CD is a guitar lovers dream. He plays the guitar as only Eric Clapton can. If you like blues you will like this CD.

B00004XONN|3.0|Here's the truth I've learned about most records that divide a bands fan base right down the middle. You know what I'm talking about right, a record where one half of the bands fans proclaim the record as a work of genius, while the other complain about how it's crap? Well, here's that truth: both sides are, nine times out of ten, wrong. Usually the truth lies somewhere in the middle. And Radiohead's \\"Kid A\\" is is a pretty prime example.<br /><br />Now I side with the latter, this band has turned to crap, on \\"Amnesiac\\" and \\"Hail to the Thief\\" because neither record was particularly interesting to me, but \\"Kid A\\" is a whole different kind of monster. It is an interesting record, and at times a great record. But it's not an all around great record. Let me explain here.<br /><br />Many people will tell you that you need to listen to this record multiple times to absorb it all, to truly understand it's brilliance. This is partially right. You can't listen to this record as background noise, even though occasionally(\\"Kid A\\", \\"Treefingers\\")that's exactly what it sounds like. But I doubt you will find brilliance after many repeating listens. Many people assume that a record as dense as this must be great, that if as much as work went into recording it as it seems there was with \\"Kid A\\", well then man it has to be great. But this isn't true.<br /><br />Now, as I have stated previously, \\"Kid A\\" does in fact flirt with brilliance at times and achieves. \\"Everything In It's Right Place\\" is an excellent mood setter, with lead singer Thom Yorke mumbling lines like \\"yesterday I woke up sucking on a lemon\\" over the type of moody, quiet synthesizers. \\"The National Anthem\\" rocks a bass line that is familiar and origanel at the same time, and rocks a horn section that Morphine would have killed for. \\"Idioteque\\" is, in my opinion, the best electronic song these guys have done, a tense, dark track that appears to be about the end of the world, with Yorke sounding as though he's recording the vocals locked in a tight, airless cage. It's starangely horrifying on your first listen, yet compelling. And \\"Optimistic\\" evokes what the timeless Joy Division would have sounded like had Ian Curtis lived a little while longer.<br /><br />But that's about it. The rest of the tracks(with the exception of \\"How to Diassapear Completley\\" which is pretty good if unremarkable) are basically just background noise, confusing enough to please Aphex Twins fans but quiet enough to sound perfectly in place in at a dentists office, except \\"Kid A\\", which is a long, dull drone of a song that goes nowhere for way to long.<br /><br />\\"Kid A\\" is neither the great record it's enthusiasts have imagined nor the unlistenable piece of garbage it's detractors will have you believe. I mean, a record with such passionate feelings has to be decent right? It is worth a listen. The band gets points for trying to bridge out a bit right? Defintely, ecspecially in todays tired rock community. But trying doesn't mean achieving. Radiohead achieve what they aspire for with \\"Kid A\\" about fifty percent of the time. But that's jsut not good enough to make this record great.cked in a tight, airless cage. It's starangely horrifying on your first listen, yet compelling. And \\"Optimistic\\" evokes what the timeless Joy Division would have sounded like had Ian Curtis lived a little while longer. <br />But that's about it. The rest of the tracks(with the exception of \\"How to Diassapear Completley\\" which is pretty good if unremarkable) are basically just background noise, confusing enough to please Aphex Twins fans but quiet enough to sound perfectly in place in at a dentists office, except \\"Kid A\\", which is a long, dull drone of a song that goes nowhere for way to long. <br />\\"Kid A\\" is neither the great record it's enthusiasts have imagined nor the unlistenable piece of garbage it's detractors will have you believe. I mean, a record with such passionate feelings has to be decent right? It is worth a listen. The band gets points for trying to bridge out a bit right? Defintely, ecspecially in todays tired rock community. But trying doesn't mean achieving. Radiohead achieve what they aspire for with \\"Kid A\\" about fifty percent of the time. But that's jsut not good enough to make this record great.

B00092ZL80|4.0|Take two legendary groups from the '70's and '80's, put them in one of the greatest venues in the USA, and prepare yourself for one unforgettable show! Both groups perform all their best hits, and even join forces for many of them. The sound is amazing on most of it, but there was one problem, which I'll cover below. Notably absent from this concert was Peter Cetera, whose voice was omnipresent on so many of Chicago's songs. Keith Howland performed most of the songs Cetera sang on the albums, and did so quite well. But I still would have preferred to have the original voice there. Howland was one of the younger band members (definitely not one of the originals), but was as adept with Chicago's songs as any of the founding members, all of whom must be in their 60's by now. Robert Lamm looked and sounded great; there must be a picture of him somewhere doing the Dorian Gray bit. I mentioned a problem with the sound; apparently, on the second disc, the DTS track is missing the rear channels. Being an audiophile, I prefer DTS over Dolby Digital when the choice is available. But the Dolby Digital track on disc 2 is complete with rear channels. I have to wonder if Image Entertainment is aware of this problem. It's due to this that I give this set only 4 stars rather than 5. I'm not aware of any albums available in surround from Earth, Wind, and Fire, but Chicago II and V are available on DVD-Audio with full 5.1 sound.Both are worth adding to your collection.

1563894696|5.0|I've always been a big Batman fan, but I'm convinced that just about anybody could read this story and enjoy it.  With the release of \\"Batman Begins\\", I got the itch to return to my childhood roots and once again discover the dark world of Gotham City.  I wasn't disappointed.<br /><br />What really makes this story great is the mystery.  Gotham City is run under the iron fist of the Falcone crime family.  It appears nothing can stop them until one Halloween night one of their members gets shot to death.  So begins a string of murders that baffles the Dark Knight to no end.  The story moves fast enough to keep you interested, but important detail isn't spared.  Like Star Wars, Batman has a cluster of recognizable characters that are truly special.  Jeph Loeb has a real knack for handling these characters in just the right way.  Tim Sale's illustrations also fit the tone perfectly.  The mystery builds great momentum as you move along, and when you reach the climax you most certainly won't be disappointed.  This is a story of trust, murder, deception, and Two-Face, one of Batman's more tragic villains.<br /><br />If you like comics or Batman, then you should have already read this because it's a classic.  If you think comics are just for kiddies, then this is a good one to pick up and try.
0446310786|5.0|This is one of those works I reread ever few years.  Each time I read this wonderful novel I am even more impressed than the last time. Had I read this in my early teens or late teens, I am not sure I would have like it all that well myself. That being said, I do feel that any reader will be much richer, in the long run, for having read this work.  I highly recommend.

B00005JNJT|5.0|I'll not mince words, I'll not try to feign some foreign objectivity in this review; I am a fan boy. A comic fan boy, a Batman fan boy. So, obviously, I went into Batman Begins with certainly a different mind set than most. A mind set of great hope for the quality of the film, and, if that hope was dashed, an elevated level of dislike and disappointment. I happily report that upon viewing this film, there was absolutely no need for feelings of disappointment on my part. The movie is, simply put, perfect. If not as a film in its own right, than as an faithful adaptation of the character of Batman. <br /> <br />So, where to begin my critique? Well, the heart of every film is its story/plot, so I'll start there. Begins' is excellent. I've known it for quite some time, having read the script to the film over a year ago (even wrote a review about it), so there really wasn't anything \\"shocking\\" for me in that department. But still, what impressed me the most about the Begins script months ago, once again impressed me on the screen. The story is simply huge. In both scope and depth of plot. A LOT happens in this movie. More than anything that's happened in the previous Batman movies, maybe more than anything that's happened in any superhero movie. This, thusly means no minutes are wasted in Begins; every scene has a purpose and serves a point to the plot. Which makes the movie quickly paced and never, ever boring. I never go into a lot of plot detail in my reviews, but suffice it to say there are plenty of twists, turns, emotional impacts that will keep your eyes locked to the screen. Including an end scene which may not just be one of the most iconic scenes ever, but also drops a big hint of the great things to come in Batman's adventures and, hopefully, in Begins' sequel. <br /> <br />The thing that impressed me the most about the film was the acting. Every performance is stellar. Probably the best cast and performance since the Lord of the Rings. And not only is everyone excellent, they each give breath life into their character, and give it a...personality all its own. Liam Neeson as Ducard plays the perfect mentor role, just as he has done repeatedly during his career. Michael Caine proves himself to be the best Alfred ever; balancing wit and concern for his Master without becoming a nag. Morgan Freeman is almost endearing as the film's \\"Q\\" character; providing Bruce with all the necessary equipment to become the legend he desires to be. Gary Oldman simply is Jim Gordon, quickly become an almost impromptu sidekick of Batman's, and does so in a way that's both fun (sometimes even funny) and smart. And Cillian Murphy as The Scarecrow does the most of his somewhat limited screen time and steals every scene he's in. And doing it without stealing the movie; a flaw of the previous Batman films and villains. He's marvelously creepy, and simply devours his dialog and spits it back out with a fervor and passion you don't often see. I'll definitely be paying close attention to Murphy's burgeoning career, as he may indeed turn out to be something quite special in the acting world in years to come. Also, mentions should also go out to Tom Wilkinson and Rutger Hauer for their supporting rolls as Carmine Falcone and Mr. Earl respectively. These are professionals, and they display their expertise in every scene. <br />Then at the center of this grand opera of oscar-caliber acting, there is Christian Bale. The fan favorite. The cult icon. He is...amazing. He gives, without a doubt in my mind, the best portrayal of a superhero ever. Even surpassing the late, great Christopher Reeve. He gives Bruce a personality that, frankly, I have never fully seen before. Even in the definitive Batman: The Animated Series. As Batman, Bale is animal. In every scene of the word. The crutches in the shadows, perches upon rooftops, and barks orders to all around him. If you ever wondered exactly how someone could be afraid of a guy dressed up in a Bat costume, Bale more than answers your question. You could be afraid. You would be afraid. Bale's Wayne is really a four dimensional character, which each one done to perfection. We see Bruce go from a lost, troubled adolescent, to a hardened, but just as lost, man, and then finally becoming the Bruce Wayne he should be. The Bruce Wayne we all know. Only a bit different. A bit better. This is something I was specially amazed by. So far, we have either seen Bruce Wayne as a cold, remote...shell of a man really in the previous films, and even the cartoon, or as a flat out jerk in the comics. Bale sidesteps either of these personalities. Instead he becomes something much more human and relatable. A person you truly feel sympathy for. As much as Bale's Batman is an animal, Bale's Bruce Wayne is a person. And a damned good one, at that. <br /> <br />Of course, the \\"real\\" Bruce, he must create an outward, playboy persona to deter any...suspicions, and, unsurprisingly, Bale does this perfectly as well. Taking a page from his performance in \\"American Psycho,\\"  Bale makes Bruce into the ultimate billionaire airhead. He's selfish, conceited, and downright stupid. A newspaper headline near the end of the film most notably spells that out. The performance is almost funny, without ever being campy or overly silly. <br /> <br />As for Katie Holmes, an actress I have little love for, she actually does quite well herself. Her performance is definitely the weakest of any of the main characters, but it's by no means bad. I wasn't expecting much from the character of Rachel, after I had grown to loath her since reading the script, but Holmes did a pretty good job of breathing life into the character and actually making her...likable. While her performance could be topped, you really can't complain. <br /> <br />Visually, Begins is many things. From the ice and snow-capped mountains of Bhutan (which is almost a cross between Lord of the Rings and Nolan's previous film \\"Insomnia\\"), to green and bright images of Bruce's childhood, to the dark and Blade Runner-esque shots of Gotham City, there is one consistent; excellent cinematography and rich pallet of colors, effectively touched up by the bleach bypassing process the film went through. Nolan's cinematographer certainly adapted his styled perfectly to fit the world of \\"Batman Begins,\\" making the film seem both epic and claustrophobic, when needed. There's nothing I love more than a beautifully shot film, and Batman definitely pleased me in this area. While \\"Begins\\" isn't quite the best shot film I've ever seen (that mantle goes to LOTR), it's definitely one of the best, and anyone like me who takes enjoyment out of that area of film should be quite pleased. <br /> <br />Howard and Zimmer's score for Batman Begins is much different from the now-classic Danny Elfman score, but that's a good thing, as Begins' atmosphere is so different from the previous films. A completely score was needed, and composers did an wonderful job of reinventing Batman's themes. While I must say I still prefer Elfman's score, the Howard/Zimmer score is very strong in its own right, and leaves no room for complaints. It doesn't have a main, recognizable theme like Elfman's, it's not really noticeable, and, once again, seems to \\"fit\\" with the mood of the movie. <br /> <br />The Special Effects are particularly noticeable. And for just the right reasons. Instead of a sterile, CGI-created environment, Nolan went back to basics, and had nearly all of the effects done the old fashioned way; with real people  Shocking, I know, but amazingly effective. Nothing looks fake about Batman Begins, when Batman's gliding through the sky, it looks like he's gliding through the sky, when the Batmobile's crashing through Gotham, it looks like it's really happening, and why shouldn't it? It was real. <br /> <br />That brings me to my next points; Nolan's \\"vision\\" of Gotham, and, probably the soon to be legendary, Batmobile chase through the city. Gotham is much different in this film than it ever was previously, and personally, I love the change. While I firmly believe Burton's Gothic style in 1989's BATMAN was beauty in every sense of the word, it did have its flaws; Gotham seemed small, and subtly artificial. Nolan corrects this, \\"opening up\\" Gotham by combining a London airplane hanger of sets and the city of Chicago itself to make Gotham look more like a real city, than just a child's nightmare. As for the Batmobile chase, it is as high-caliber as everything else in the film. This Batmobile (also called The Tumbler) does things no one would ever dream, let alone seen, a car doing before. I wouldn't be surprised if it becomes one of the more famous car chases in the history of film when all's said and done. <br /> <br />Nolan's direction of Batman Begins isn't as...noticeably brilliant as some of his other films, but it is still very strong, and still better than most directors in Hollywood. The film is edited quite well, and judging from the acting performances of the film, his direction to his actors must have been suburb as well. He's definitely turned out, at least, his second best film in Batman Begins. <br /> <br />But now, sadly, I must address the flaw in the movie. Every film's got at least one, and Begins has its own; the cinematography during fight sequences. Many have already criticized Nolan for this. Quite severely, in fact. I wouldn't go quite as far. The fight scenes aren't horrible, they're just simply not the best in the world. I can almost see where Nolan was coming from in his choice of shooting the fights with many quick-cuts and close ups. It's confused, hurried and disoriented; which is exactly what a fight with Batman would be like. So, it's not bad in terms of realism, but for viewing enjoyment, it falls a bit short. <br /> <br />Overall though, I'd have to say without a doubt, Batman Begins is not only one of the best films of the year, but also the most well-made film in its genre yet.

B000007NYS|5.0|Actually, four and a half stars.  Anybody who comes out with a CD as astonishingly good as \\"Car Wheels On A Gravel Road\\" is destined to have all other recordings compared against that one.  So, although Spin magazine recently ranked LW among the 100 greatest CDs of the past 20 years (curiously omitting \\"Car Wheels\\"), for me it falls a bit short of that towering achievement.    The difference on this eponymous CD is that the delivery and the arrangements don't always match the (consistent) excellence of the songwriting.  \\"Changed The Locks\\" is a good example, I think Tom Petty's version was more convincing.    But there's very little to gripe about here, and the highs are both numerous and reach very high indeed. Lucinda delivers songs such as \\"Abandoned\\", \\"Am I Too Blue\\", and \\"Side Of The Road\\" with complete emotional conviction.  She leaves no doubt that she has not only written outstanding songs but has also recorded the definitive versions.    On most of the songs here there is a perfect marriage of lyrics, music, and arrangement.  The lyrics are superb, at times very personal, and always evocative (\\"she's holding a Corona and it's cold against her hand\\").  Delivering lyrics this good with accompanying music that wrenches all of the emotion out of it underscores what a musical treasure Lucinda Williams is.  Thank God she's no longer unknown.  \\"Car Wheels..\\" is still the first choice, but neither this nor \\"Essence\\" will disappoint.
B0002XDODU|4.0|\\"Reise, Reise\\" is the much-awaited follow-up to 2001's BRILLIANT \\"Mutter\\" album, and, thankfully, it delivers. It retains the sound explored in Mutter, a more orchestral and epic sound than that of the technometal of their first two albums. There is some new experimentation, though, mostly in songs like \\"Los\\" and \\"Moskau\\". Overall, it sounds somewhat more lively than Mutter's brooding and dark tone, while still retaining said tone in some songs (Stein Um Stein, Ohne Dich). The only problem that I feel makes it a slightly inferior album to Mutter is the fact that a few songs (Keine Lust, Morgenstern, Amerika) don't quite flow as perfectly as they did in Mutter, although they're still great songs! Either way, it is a great album despite the large number of softer tracks (Los, Ohne Dich, Amour) and the lack of trully heavy fast rockers. It is mostly an epic mid-tempo metal album, and it rocks! <br /> <br />Song by song review: <br /> <br />1) Reise, Reise: The title track opens perfectly where Mutter left off; a heavy mid-tempo anthemic track. The chorus is huge, catchy, and inspiring while the instrumentation is purely EPIC, you'll feel you're in an ancient ship as it rides into a foggy, stormy sea. Think Seeman by way of Mein Herz Brennt or Mutter. The accordion at the end is classic. 9/10 <br /> <br />2) Mein Teil: The lead-off single opens with a BANG. THe song is quite creepy in the verses, and again huge catchy choruses that DEMAND your attention. It's pure metal chaos, and the outro is again, bone-chilling. 9/10 <br /> <br />3) Dalai Lama: The weakest track on the album, but still a good track. Very similar to the previous album's \\"Spielhur\\" (but better) with a little bit of \\"Klavier\\" thrown in: long, a tragic child-centric story. It drags a little, but the choruses are immensly creepy, they'll send shivers down your spine, while the pre-choruses are HEAVY. Very epic. 7/10 <br /> <br />4) Keine Lust: The third single. This song gets pretty heavy and fast in thebeggining with the verses and choruses respectively before exploding into epic tragic second chorus that shout \\"Mir Ist Kalt! So Kalt!\\" (I am cold, so cold). The second half of the song is where it really picks up, as this chorus keeps getting bigger and more epic. 8/10 <br /> <br />5) Los: This song is basically a huge wordplay in german, as los can mean \\"-less\\" [the prefix], \\"loose\\", or \\"go!\\". The lyrics are very cool, kind of \\"You can't stop us\\" lyrics, which is ironic given the laid-back sound of the song. It's the least rammstein-ish song they've ever done [while still decidedly Rammstein), a very cool bluesy track. breaks up the album  pretty nicely. Simply a great song, despite it not being metal. 8.5/10 <br /> <br />6) Amerika: The big single. It's a pretty good song, catchy chorus, good for a single. The highlight is the solo. It is definitely awesome. 7.5/10 <br /> <br />7) Moskau: A fast and insanely catchy song (much better than Amerika, in my opinion), would've been a great single. They originially wanted the TATu girls to sing, but there was some management problem. The song features the accordion again, which just gives it that extra classy touch. Flows great, and is a great rocker. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />8) Morgenstern: This is a very good song, despite that fact that it feels a little broken up. The gothic choruses are simply amazing, with the church choir sending shivers down one's spine. However, the verses are VERY heavy. Both parts are good, they just sound somewhat awkward in the transitions. Either way, just the amazing choruses and lyrics make it increadibly good. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />9) Stein Um Stein: Another creepy song, this one again changes from slow, creeping verses to insanely heavy stomping choruses (kind of like the opposite of Morgenstern). Till really SCREAMS in this one, and both transitions after the chorus are done very well. A humorous note, the last word of the bridge is ramm, and after the pause Till screams \\"STEIN!\\". The \\"solo\\"is awesome. 9/10 <br /> <br />10) Ohne Dich: The first ballad, very heartfelt and also catchy. The string section in it is very well implemented. Reminds me a little of \\"Seeman\\", but with an EPIC catchy chorus. Both the heavy and the light parts sound great, and wow... just the orchestration. It seems like an awesome closer and again, quite epic, like Reise, Reise. Beautiful. 9/10 <br /> <br />11) Amour: It seems a bit of an afterthought, and yet, it fits perfectly. It's more reserved than Ohne Dich, but not as beautiful. The lyrics are one of my favourite parts \\"Love, everyone just wants to tame you, Love, in the end, caught between your teeth\\".  8.5/10 <br /> <br />Overall, Reise, Reise would be a GREAT addition to your collection if you're a fan or even a newcomer. It is fairly accessible, not to mention a HELL of an album.
630460288X|4.0|Sandra Bullock kills every movie she's ever in, so that is my reason for the 4 stars instead of 5. She really just gets on my nerves. The story has been talked about already, but I will say that some of the ideas presented were as interesting as the action itself. For instance, in the car they listen to the most popular radio station in town which is really just commercial jingles, getting the public to sing along about products being sold. Scary to think we are halfway to that reality as it is. This movie is full of useless one-liners that almost every american action film is required to have. They aren't as annoying as arnold's movies, and the delivery is pretty funny so it isn't too bad. The action scenes are clearly the standout moments, the one in the museum being the best in the film. Definitely worth seeing, i picked it up on vhs for 2 bucks at a used record store, can't beat that.
